text: Bottle at Drie Fonteinen, Lambik-o-Droom...shared with the wife, cheers~! Pours a lightly hazy golden color. Hues of copper. Small eggshell head. Aromas are pure bliss! Does gueuze smell better than this?! Tons of barnyard, horse blanket, citrus, oak, light hay, light bread. Taste follows, with a nicely tart citrus note, fading into dry, funky brett...horse blanket, leather. Depths of oak follow with a very soft moth feel, despite a medium carbonation. Finishes with a light bread note, medium tart, citrus, oak and more horse blanket. Fucken awesome!
Vintage 2010 @ Lambik O Droom. Clear golden body with a medium white head. Tart, oak, cellar, cobwebs, lemon, fruity. Lovely.

Bottle, 375 ml, 2012 at Lambik-o-droom with Hoon, kraddel, Robin, Travlr, Miro. Pours hazy golden with small white head. Citrus, funky, barnyard, intensive, wood, sour, dry finish. Complex and balanced. Medium bodied. Really enjoyed this one.

750ml bottle at 3 fon droom location. Pours out a golden peach apricot color topped with a white head. Nose is nice light fruit notes tons of bugs and funk. Taste is more of the buggy funk notes a very nice soft end.
St. Valentijn Cuvée (2007). Donker gele-oranje kleur met kleine witte schuimkraag. Straffe graanachtige geur met een toets van citrus. Smaak is hout en eindigt in intens zure pompelmoes.

Bottle. Hazy orange colour. Funky, musty, yeasty, barnyard aroma and taste. Leather, earth, cork, wood. Tart, sour, astringent, dry. Very, very dry. Citrus-fruity (grapefruit & lemon). Fresh, sour green apples. Great beer. (2008)

2010 Vintage. Bottle at Cafe Rose Red, Bruges, 11th February 17. Shared in company of wife and kids, consumed alone :) pours rich straw, clear. Aroma is hay, sour, vineous, smooth, farmyard. Taste is so smooth, tart, tasty, complex, rich, wood, slight smoke. Excellent.

Bottle shared by "hannont". Colour..lightly cloudy gold with a thin white head. Nose...heavy, heady orchard fruits and acetic notes with good ol barnyard funk and horsey blankie. Palate...lightly tart and acetic with lots of preppy fruit skins and pulpy goodness. The mid palate is tight and dry and the finish is tangy, tart and slightly sulpherous.
These lambic is always impress. Every flavor of the country imaginable in the aroma and flavor. As it warmed it took on a farm leather gunpowder flavor profile. On the sweeter side with high carb.

2010 Bottle. Pours a lightly hazy slightly murky golden yellow with a mostly lasting fluffy off white head. Aroma is of citrus, biscuits, lime, funky, barnyard, grassy, white grapes, melon, pear. Taste is of citrus, pear, melon, grapes, hint of stone fruit, lightly acidic, funky, tannic, really smooth. Oily mouthfeel, soft to medium carbonation.

A small taste from a friend (bottle) @ Pikkulintu. 2007 vintage. Pours hazy amber with a low head. Aroma is sour malts, vinegar and blue cheese. Flavor is sour malts, vinegar and some blue cheese. You can taste the age. Still awesome.

From notes. Enjoyed at a tasting Kyle finally made it to at Mickeys on December 01. 750 mL bottle, 2012 vintage. The pour is a nice hazy golden orange color with a thick white head that slowly recedes with a light soapy lace left. The aroma is pretty damn good. There is a nice dry oak and a good citrus acidity up front. A good mineral addition comes through with a lovely funkiness and a hint of brett. The flavor is much of the same. Its balanced, sour, tart, citric, funky, and just everything you want. The mineral addition is a little surprising, but well balanced. The mouth feel is a touch heavy for what it should be and well carbonated. The aftertaste is lingering funkiness and citric acid. Its a great beer.

[2012] 750ml bottle. Slightly hazy orange with a foamy white head. Flavors are burnt plastic, oak, lemon, stone fruits and cheese with fruity and acetic notes. Medium body, good carbonation, slick texture.
An opaque orange-gold with dry oaky funk and banana bread aroma. Full bodied, super dry, ascerbic, cork, lots of citrus and is just super good.

Vintage 2012 bottle 0.75 lt. Colour between orange and amber a little hazy with thin head. Very complex aroma and taste. Spicy aroma with light notes of leather, farmyard, mushrooms, green apple, hay and slightly vinegary too. Taste starts with tart note to progress towards notes of tangerine and citrus. It's ready to drink but it should improve with ageing. I loved the complexity and the quite long finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle at the brewery. Moderately tart, tanninish. Also slightly vinegary, but not too much. Quite good, yet completely different taste profile from the classic version at this time. I like tha classic better.
Bottle at brewery. Pours golden color, white head. Aroma of bret, sour, oranges. Taste is sour, tangerines, bret, orange.

From bottle at the source, 2012 bottle. Pours a hazy orangy amber with a small white head. Aroma has lots of funk, green apples, oak, light leather, barnyard, spice. Taste is sour, funky, slight Stone fruity sweetness, champagne-dry finish. High carbonation and a smooth body.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2016 Bottle @ Lambik O Droom. 2012 vintage. Pours bright juicy orange with some chunks and a small white head. Aromas of vinegar, orange, citrus, mushrooms, hay, mandarin. Taste has orange, mandarin, forrest floor, dry, vinegary, tannins, walnuts, bitter citrus, light burning sourness.

2012 version, at Lambik-o-droom. Slightly hazy dark golden color with creamy beige head. Aroma starts with hay, dry meadow flowers, unripe stonefruits and some lemon. Taste starts tart upfront with unripe fruits, but also with a fruit pits, seeds and skin bitterness. Hay and farmhouse notes throughout, funky but not too extreme. Light to medium body, dry, light to medium carbonation. A really well rounded gueuze, sour but quite easy to drink, funky but not cloying.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2016 2008 version in beersel. Pours a hazy golden yellow from the bottle with bubbly white head that dissipates slowly. Aroma of huge funk notes and mild tart lemony citrus. Taste is more balanced with big funk and acidity, hugely complex. A very nice treat to try this.

Bottle at the brewery, 2012 vintage. Hazy bright orange with a thin white head and visible carbonation. Notes of peaches, apricots, barnyard funk, lactic acid, mineral components, salt, macerated apples, grape vinegar, light apple cider. Medium body with high carbonation and a sour and refreshing aftertaste. Delicious.
Bottle at lambik-O-droom. Clear golden with white head. Aroma of vinegar, very sharp! Taste is fruity yeast, dry, slightly tart, very nice fruity taste, dry/bitter finish.

Aroma and taste has nice citric lemon notes, some honey, straw, nice funky notes, medium acidity, fruity finish.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

2007 St Valentijn bottle at Koelschip. Pours clear golden with a medium white head which recedes to a small figment of a head. Aroma is grassy, funk, oak and a hint of sweet sugar. Taste is moderate sour, some sweetness, citrus lemon, sweaty funk. Full bodied with a modest carbonation.

Bottle @ lambic o droom, tasted side by side with regular. Pours almost clear golden with a white head. Aroma of green apples, moldy, barn, light acetone, stonefruits, citrus. Taste is quite acedic, with a tad too much acetone, tho a very nice blend with lots of good fruits,. Imo fresh oude geueze is way better.

2012 vintage at 3F in Lot. Side by side to a fresh 2015, December bottle.  The old one is deep and intense in the nose, not too funky or fruity. The beer starts smooth with slightly souring hints. Lots of sourish woody depth, fresh, intense, wood. Long intense slightly funky but sourish horse blanket aftertaste. Fantastic and much more settled than the younger version!
Great!
Pours a cloud golden Orange with a white lacing. The aroma is vinegar, berries, grape skin. Wilted flower and leather.

750 mL bottle, Bottled 12/27/2007. Reviewed from notes.

Deep orange with a small head. Clings nicely. Maybe its just this bottle, but it lacks a bit of the impressive stature of regular Oude Geuze.

Awesome peppery funk aroma. Heavy hay. Tang citrus that hints towards its sourness. Pepper above all. I love the way 3F gueuzes smell.

Citrus flavor is more prominent. Orange. Wheat graininess. Pepper in the finish with less funk and a touch of oak.

Medium body. A bit heavy for the style and lowish carbonation. Not as effervescent as Id like.

I dont know if this is better than regular Oude Geuze. I guess Id need to try them side by side. Armand blends the best gueuzes and this is no exception. Phenomenal.
2010 bottle. Hazy orange shade. Quite a lot of head. Dusty aroma, light apricot, jammy fruits. Taste of fruit rinds, quite dry, not too sour. Great balance and drinkability. Lovely.
2012 bottle Dark orange color. Sweetened gueuze. Apricot and cheese flavor and apricot nose. Medium mouthfeel. Long juicy finish. Very good.

(750ml bottle 2012 vintage) cloudy deep gold, fine white bubbles. Nose is unique, oak, juicy fruit, stone fruit, mild funk and so cool. Taste of juicy fruit, light funk, oak, yogurt, oranges and medium carb.

Bottle: 4/15/2003

848417

Deep golden orange with a consistent off white head. Funky aroma. Barnyard, lemon, damp oak, wet basement, horsey. Citric acidity in the flavor. Bone dry flavor. Some lemony acidity, damp oak, horsey barnyard. Mineraly and earthy. Some cheese rind. Extremely dry and complex funkiness. A nice Gueuze.

UPDATED: MAY 7, 2017 4/7/2016. At Lambik-O-Droom opening weekend. 37,5 cl Bottle vintage 2012. Near clear orange golden with thin white ring head and active bubbling. Very rich aroma of hay, almonds, wood, grass, dough, lemon, grapfruit, peach, apricot, grapes, nutmeg. Medium sour on a rich fruity base, light bitter and strong minerallike character and saltiness. Over medium body, firm fizzy carbonation. Lovely tart fruity finish. This is fantastic beer! 
2016. At Maakuns surprise birthday party. Vintage 2010. Bottle shared by Maakun. Hazy dark golden/orange, thin white head. Grapes, hayish, lemon, vanilla, soft smooth edge, grape and peach stones. Medium sour. Very light carbonation. Nice and soft and full of flavor. (4.5) 



2016/11/23 At deansos courtesy of kermis vintage 2007. Very soft, nutty, cobwebby and dry. Very nice. 
2017. Birthday beer, 37,5 cl. Hay, horseblanket, grapestones, almonds, apricot, lime, nutmeg, cobwebs, massive funk. Very nice. Very juicy.

UPDATED: SEP 3, 2016 Bottle 2010 vintage 37.5 cl shared at my birthday. Hazy orange golden with small white head that leaves a nice ring with little bubbles. Massive funk, white grapes, fresh lemon, typical 3F twigs leaves and some pepper, but also a soft sweet fruity aroma cutting through, some light fresh cardboard, quite some grains, sour grains too, grassy, light sweaty cheese. Nice balance between sourness, light sweetness and lingering bitter finish. Medium bodied with soft sparkly carbonation. Super yummie, happy birthday to me. 4.5


2012 vintage 37.5 at their new location. Similar to the above, with more white pepper, light sulphur, white wine vinegar. Lots of fruit still. Slightly less bitter than the 2010 one. Ridiculously good, absolutely mind blowing.
Dit bier is echt één van de grootste smaakbommen die ik ooit geproefd heb. Zeker als ze een paar jaar gelegen hebben is het smaakpalet zo volledig, zo complex.. Deze flessen doen naar meer smakken!

St valentÿn cuvée 14.02.2007
Looks.. Yellow amber, sml head.
Smells..older lambic dank, earthy
Tastes.. So soft, still a slight carbonation. Lemon and green apples and the acidic punch is just so so soft, a little oak. Im just gonna stop writing and get back to drinking this amazing aged lambic.

750 ml bottle out of a basket, thanks AdamC, 2008 vintage. Aroma is huge funky yeast, light fruit and fecal matter. 
The flavor has a low vinegar element with a big funky tartness. Maybe a very mild metallic hint. The texture is very dry, bone dry. The yeast gives a very light pucker. I got to say, I may never love the style but I understand what this is. This batch was blessed by the Brewer, was very happy to sample this.

Another treat brought from the hoprider. 
Pour amber, with a small white head that quickly turns into a thin ring of white head. 
Aroma brings my mind towards unripe peaches. Ever trues lickig a peach Stone? Every thing Else is somewhat subdued, but very well integrated - lemon peel, horseblanked. Pretty darn well made. 
Taste is sour and tart of course, but very well balanced. Medium bodied, with less carb. Than usual. This is an example of how to blend everything togethers in a Way, that nothing stands out, but everything stands out... You know?

Bottle, 14.02.2007, St Valentijn Cuvée, enjoyed 8 years after bottling. Pours hazy golden, with a big creamy head. Aroma is bretty wood, nuts and lactic acid, with funky farmyard and earthy notes, as well as hay and crisp citrusy notes. Full body, with soft carbonation. Flavour is tart with bretty floral and wooden notes, as well as nice farmyardy funk and stone fruits. Funky sour finish, with citrusy notes of grapefruit. Tremendously balanced, and very drinkable.

Bouteille 37.5cl, bottled 12/04/2005.
De couleur orangée portant un léger voire, col col est épais et crémeux blanc-cassé mais sestompant relativement vite.
Arôme offre un bouquet funk modéré, retrouve un fruité citronné offrant des effluves citriques sans pour cela être surfait, rétro boisé avec un côté grains restant de la partie même après autant dannées.
Palais est sec, petite note de cuire, funk bien citrique qui rajoute à cette impression de feuilles séchées. Boisé nest pas en reste et contribue à ce profil sic finement épicé. Acidulé perce sur la fin tout en restant appréciable, note également une pointe dacidité de citron tout en gardant un aspect grains-moût sur la fin. Correcte, quant à savoir si les 10 ans lui ont fait un boni cela reste à discuter.

Muddy orange color with some foam. The smell has surprisingly little old feet in the nose for a gueze. Distinct sourness with a mild funkiness, which results in a different gueze than expected. Dry and sour aftertaste.

Thanks to Seth for the 08 bottle share. Its OGV, its great, its got an almost unreal stone fruit character that comes naturally without any fruit needed, what more must be said? A timeless classic.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2017 Rerate at Lambik-o-Droom, 2008 vintage. Still lives up to its reputation. Pours cloudy amber with a decent head. Aroma is funk over stables and dried fruit, some hay. Body is medium, with a good acidity and tartness, lemonade-like. Lightly vinegary. Palate has more of that, rather dry. Great balance and texture. Outstanding. Bottle at Zwanze Day Zurich 15, 2003 vintage. The definite geuze, yup. Rating from one sip is discouraged, but I have to do it.

UPDATED: FEB 4, 2017 2003, with Toni and anstei and co. At Zwanze 2015. Hazy golden-orange color with big white head. Funk and wood, bretts, citrus oil. Taste is citrus, red apples, grapes. Good complexity. Soft foamy mouthfeel. A fantastic Geuze again. 9-4-10-5-182012 bottle at the Lambik-O-Droom. Hazy golden-orange golor with white head. Aroma is black bread crust, lemony, citrus oil, bright apples, dry woody funk. Taste is black bread, lemony, again citrus oil. Very dry finish, carbonation is "moussierend". A beautiful Geuze. 9-4-9-5-17.

2010 vintage consumed 12th Sept 2015, a week after it was released. Pours murky orange with a big head. Loads of carbonation. Aroma is that unmistakeable funky 3F house style. Taste has loads of Granny Smith, hay, citric lemon, minerally, very sour, some mild acetone at first but this went away as the beer began to breath. Superb.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone
user_location: The big bad LDN, Greater London, ENGLAND

text: St. Valentijn Cuvee 2007. The beer is a deep yellow-orange amber color. Quite cloudy but it would settle out more with gentler handling. Small off white head, dissipates quickly. The aroma has wonderful funk and depth with lots of earth but the oak is fairly strong and dominates a bit compared to other vintages. Mushrooms, very light apricots, a touch of citrus. Taste has a lot of oak. Fairly bitter, really. The depth is there but theres a funny malt flavor. Medium body. Not a great year for this beer. Ill revisit this rating and probably adjust it up quite a bit.

750 ml bottle. Vintage 2007, St. Valentijn with a synthetic cork. 
Aroma is rather herbal and earthy with a light woodiness as well. Some light lemon notes and hints of stone fruit. A light oak character. Really nice herbal notes and some moderate funk. 
Pours a hazy, golden copper color and a medium sized, somewhat thin, white head with decent retention as it recedes to a thin film that lingers. Medium lacing and small legs. 
Flavor has a light sweetness and moderate acidity. Medium oak notes. Light citrus character and faint stone fruit. Moderate woody, earthy notes with lighter herbal and barnyard funk. Moderate mineral notes. 
Mouthfeel is medium bodied with medium carbonation. Low astringnecy and low alcohol warmth. 
Overall, not my favorite vintage that I have had. Too much oak in the flavor. Nice herbal and funky notes and a good mineral quality. I think I would prefer standard Fonteinen OG to this particular vintage.

2007 Vintage. Cloudy amber colour, white head. Aroma has nice sourness, black pepper, caramel, bit apricot. Nice sourness and tartness, salty caramel, fruits, sorbus. Balanced and not overpowering sourness. Treat.

vintage 2008 bottle at home, recieved in a trade. poured a clear golden to light orange colour with white head on top, dusty aroma hits the nose, barnyeard, sour rotten green apples, hay, stone fruits, lemon, very sour tannic mouthfeel. lots of oak notice, horseblanket, grape skin, way more complex and tart compared to their regular geuze, cheese, some grain notice, soft and smooth carbonation, awesome stuff, very enjoyable!
Bottle 08 - pours light Amber. Nose is lemony, tart, acidic, oaky. Taste is tart, acidic, lemon zest.
Appelgoud van kleur met witte schuimkraag die snel verdwijnt. Smaak zacht appel cider / champagne. Gedronken met Bryan en Martijn

11/2006 bottle. Was expecting the cork to shoot out on this, and nothing. Guess those synthetic cork rumors Ive heard are true. Aroma of lemon pepper, funk, Brett. Taste is mildly spur, farmhouse brett. No acid. Carbonation is low but Im assuming that has more to do with the cork issues.

UPDATED: APR 16, 2015 Bottle: 2008 vintage, yellow OGV label. Pours a solid, vibrant, semi-turbid golden sunshine-orange color with a foamy white head that fizzles a bit before receding to a small ring. Lovely aroma, exactly what youd expect from the Fonteinen terroir. Acidic stone fruits, green apple, lemon tartness, mineral water, moderate acidic, super horsey funk, sweaty feet, a bit of barnyard hay, cork, & a nice helping of wet moldy oak towards the back end, proper tannic finish. Flavor is just as great. Very sour, tons & tons of Granny Smith apple up front with a bit of lemon, peach, & white grape underneath. Acidic, but tamed... Does not burn at all. Musky funk hits hard; lots of wood, moderate horseblanket, wet hay, old cork, & a bit of sweat in the finish. Tons of wood & white grape in the back-end with a very faint acetic dip, leading to a dry, tart finish. Wow. This is better than fresh 3F Oude Geuze; it is more tart, yet more complex & subtle all around. The oak is more tame as well, & blends with the wild yeast perfectly. Is this better than a regular, aged OG? Not sure. Hopefully I will find out soon, as I have an 07 OGV waiting to be opened alongside a regular 07 OG. But in any case, this gueuze is out of this world.

2008 375ml bottle from Kamiel, so grateful to finally get to try this. The cork releases with a loud pop, not a gusher but lots of carbonation stored in this tiny bottle as it takes a while to be able to pour into the glasses without the head pouring out the top. Murky amber (poured some dregs in) with a generous and then gentle bubbly sticky white head. Slightly acidic, wet hay, some cheesecloth, epson salts, great funk, light lemon, moderate carbonation and full body, acidic, funky, dry, and incredibly complex. Delicious.
UPDATED: FEB 17, 2015 Bottle at RBBWG shared by BelgBeerGeek. Nice cheesy, sour, but very balanced. Awesome gueze, probably the best Ive ever had.

Bottle, 2008 vintage. Pours a clear golden beer with a big white head on top. Aroma has barnyard, leather, Brett and white fruits. Flavor is medium tart, a big sweet base, loads of fruit and dust in there. Decent balance, beer held up well during aging. Good stuff.

UPDATED: NOV 25, 2015 2006. Synthetic cork. Orange pour, no head. Oxidized drain-pour, more reminiscent of a mediocre aged barleywine. Some funk and brightness but otherwise too oxidized to enjoy.

2002 and 2005 enjoyed 6-19-15. 2002: nose is must, cobwebs, lemon rind. Taste follows similarly. Very similar to the Blauw I had a few months ago. 2005: much brighter with more citrus than 2002. Minerals, soft palate.

2008 750 - Orange red pour. Nose is cobwebs, funk, a touch of leather, caramel, lemon, musty, mineraly. Vibrant. Taste is sour lemon, funk. Really tart. Lingering tartness.

Vintage 2002 (I believe) sampled at THE FESTIVAL 2014 in LA with Linh and Scarlett. Pours a hazy golden body with thick white head and lasting lacing. Aroma is brilliant funk, barn, lemon, brett and light wood. Mouthfeel is near perfection - with funk, minerals, wood, funky citrus, light white wine, weathered barn and a nice bright tart character. Awesome.
Bottle from the brewery. Orange colour, white foam. Medium carbonation. Very complex and well balanced geuze. Tart, funky and dry. Medium bitter finish. Fruity notes of lemon and apple. Very good!

375 ml bottle split two ways, 08 vintage. Dark golden pour with a tiny head that quickly fades and leaves small lacings. Loads of funk, barnyard, green apples, lemon peel and some leather. So mellow but yet so complex. This is wonderful stuff!
Bottle from trade in Brussels. Aroma of rubber, some floral notes. Orange cloudy pour. Sour and dry. Medium light feel.
Bottle thanks to artmcd8. Poured hazy dark orange with thinning white head. Aroma of sour fruit funk. Light carb med bod. Tangy taste. Ok

2008 vintage thanks to Mathias. Slightly cloudy golden orange with a good creamy white head. Aroma bus barnyard funk, mature cheese, dried stone fruits, hints of preserved figs. Medium bodied, tart and funky on the palate, very well balanced and complex, lightly fruity finish. Taste is dried apricots, peach pits, mature cheddar, candied citrus, hint of sour peach candy. Delicious.
Pours hazy straw color with no head. Funky and tart nose and flavor, with hay, light malt and grapefruit. Lively mouthfeel and long tart finish.

Bottle at home with friends, courtesy of Dave. 2006 Vintage.Thanks man! Pour is slightly hazy orange with a small white head that quickly dissipated. Big funky, lemon rind, biscuit, sweet tarts, urine, slight cheese, and wax in the aroma. Taste is lemons, some grass, dough, biscuit, stone fruits, orange, and vanilla with a semi sour finish. Slick mouthfeel with almost no carbonation. Nice stuff - just wish it had more carbonation.
At Stephens 2nd annual Great American Beer Festival Tasting on 10/1/14. Pours clear orange with no head. Aroma is nice, taste is nice.

Drunk from 75 cl bottle bought in the blender in Beersel. Sharp, tart geuze. Fantastic.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: FEB 10, 2015 2007 Vintage - tasted february 2015 : dark amber pour with a stunning head. Rich earthy and mineral aromas. Splendid connected scents of barnyard, citrus, brett, white grapes, tannine. Very deep and full bodied taste character that lingers on, even in the stomach. Aging did its work! Such strength! I taste lots of apricots, some vanilla, pears, honey, apple, medium tartness and acidity, hops in the finish. What a splendid Vintage! Deep, round, potent and balanced at the same time. A 6 year vintaged vintage I will always remember!

Bottle from the brewery. Vintage 2008: released this weekend. Feature the red label artwork "Nightlights" by Felix de Boeck. Pours amber murky with small sticky foamhead. Aromas are woody, oak, cedar, orange zest, very balanced and soft to the nose... and mouth! Tart, dried apples, slight cheese taste; medium sourness and smooth acidity that finishes slightly dry to the mouth. Appreciate this Vintage for its unique smoothness, balance and character : this one of the best old gueuze blends around. Chapeau Armand!

Ive had many vintages over the years, they ranged from very good to excellent. This rating is for the 2002 Vintage (white label). Pours a blond with huge white head, spectacular. Aroma is barnyard funk, lots of cheese, oak and light menthol. Taste is so bright and well balanced between lemon and cheese with a considerable oak presence. Palate is dry (not the driest Ive seen for a beer this age) and highly carbed. It feels so fresh for such an old beer, one of the best 3F vintage Ive had.

Bottle at DHVL, 2003 vintage. Pours dark golden with a small white head. Aroma is tart citrus, apple, barnyard, light leather, oak, earth. Taste is medium acidic, with dry tart apple notes, hay, oak and a soft malty backbone. Dry lingering fruity tart finish.

UPDATED: NOV 6, 2016 Bottle from Pallieter85, many thanks my friend. Vintage 2004 I believe. Hazy orange colored with huge off-white head. Tart aroma of lemon, apples, wood, cellar aromas, funk. Taste, gentle tartness together with some sweetness, yeast, wood, brett. Dry finish. Tasty.

The 2006 vintage version, apparently a variation on the regular oude geuze but with lambic of exceptional quality. Thick, stable, sticky, off-white, densely packed foam, warm orangey colour, bright with vivid sparkling but obviously misty after adding the deposit. Complex, extremely well-balanced aroma, lactic acid, lemon juice, wheat, pineapple, kiwi, green apple, wet hay, sherry, honey... Crisp, refreshing citrussy fruitiness in the taste, lively and pungent, wheat sourishness beautifully interwoven with barley sweetishness, complexely sprawling over the tongue, dry due to sourness but never becoming astringent, very long, dry finish. Absolutely fabulous.

Bottle. 2008 vintage. Thanks to KyotoLefty. Ripe pure manure, dusty notes behind, pickles and beets. Hazy copper/straw color. Smooth yet tart mix of pickled fruit: pears, kiwi, sourish unripe cherries and apricots. Thin body, sharp on the tongue. Smooth and the complex flavor profile is astounding, all blended so well. Excellent.

2008 vintage from the brewery. Nose of tobacco, leather, grapefruit zest. Mellow flavor, nicely ages, leather, tobacco, grapefruit. Finish is very long lasting and mellow. Full, big body and flavor, well aged. Wonderful.

2005 bottle thanks to Bruce. Pours a cloudy orange with thick frothy off white head that lasts leaving sticky lacing. The aroma is strong funk, rubber, oak. Medium mouthfeel with nice juicy funk, complex yet so balanced. Really amazing stuff. 

2002 bottle thanks to Gibson. Pours a cloudy orange with medium creamy white head that lasts awhile. The aroma is feet and rubberbands. Thin mouthfeel with dry fruit and light tartness wow.

Rating from notes. This bottle was shared at Levis tasting by Brian. I am surprised to see I have not rated it before. Sour aroma of course, with earth; dirt, wild grass and some barnyard character. Flavor is very sour and dry, earthy again. Excellent.

Bottled April 2004. Despite cork easing out gently, this poured well with a nice small white head. The aroma is citrussy and musty, almost of rotting lemons. Colour is clear orange gold. Taste is amazing: initial sweetness immediately giving way to a sharp, tart citrus taste, leading to a lingering dryness and some bitterness. Little carbonation but crystalline, spiky sharpness on the tongue with a puckering dryness that lingers.
Overall a great beer. This is a great taste experience: sharp, sour , dry but all balanced leading the drinker to want another sip.

Bottle, vintage 2008 with huge thanks to Ben! Cork pulls with a satisfying pop. Pour is clear butterscotch orange with a medium off-white head that is fairly fizzy and dissipates down to a much smaller creamy remainder that nevertheless laces quite well. Aroma is light funky, barnyard, horse blanket, oak. Flavor has a bit of initial sweetness trying out quickly to a light tart, a wave of funkiness hits your palate immediately, but fades leaving the tart lemony oak notes behind. Lightish body and high carbonation. Pretty nice.

375 ml bottle via trade from Boutip. Thanks, Phil. I cant wait till the next! Pours a well hazed orange amber hue, healthy haze intertwine, some nice big carbonation through the body, good glow, hazy middle. Striking big tannish head is cakey and huge, starts to die and remains a decent cakey layer, ok lacing overall. Lots of carbonation. Aromas offer big lemony and lactic elements, yogurt and big citrusy bite, sour and inviting with some bretty funk, bread, cobwebs, and dust as it settles in. A gentle mushroom, funk grows. Sour spritzy feel sticks and dominates, quite lovely. Some crab apple, lemon, and gentle pear. Rich fruit, sour fruit flavors, a kiss of dough, rich lactic, the brett grows as it settles in. Just lovely. Initial is medium body, a bit lighter, quite drinkable, with some rich sourness up front. Lactic and lemony, crab apple, some pear. A bit harsh but up my alley, sour and lactic, a touch metallic. Yogurt, rich lemon, metal. Some barnyard, funk, gentle dough and straw into the middle get to the beer that is left. Funky, straw, and cobwebs. Some barnyard, straw. Dry overall, thin, with some rich sourness throughout. Id say it lacks the balance youve come to expect from regular Oude Gueze and will show some powerful sourness up front without acidity, perhaps some metal or vomit to others, but overall a really fun and flavorful beer, well balanced offering compared to American sours which become acedic messes quickly.. this never does at all. Consider this the Gueze you measure against American sours as far as being assertive. Its intense, a touch too much for many, but I dig it. I like the front end and the nose is heavenly. Nice damn lambic.

Around the edges of those notes are pleasing smooth and not really all that tart vinegar notes nuanced by a thin sensation of sweaty wet socks. Diggin this.

75cl bottle shared with Dutchdrebus and Joes. Slightly hazy light orange color, small off-white head. Smell rubber and sourish. Taste is very balanced, sone sourness, tart, some sharpness. Lovely finish. Medium body, subtle carbonation.

2007 version thx to benzai. Very clear golden yellow to orange colour, medium to small white head. Smells sour, dusty, cellar, car tire, plastic. Tastes sour, not that sour though, a bit thin, fruity. Low carbo and quite thin.

UPDATED: NOV 9, 2014 375 at mikkeller bar, ?04 vintage.Apricot colored with aggressive lacy head.  Clean, approachable, slightly sour but not overwhelming, finishes crisp, very nice. 04 At grote dorst. Fantastic, tart, super funky, not overwhelming.

375 mL bottle @ De Heeren van Liedekercke. Pours a clear golden orange appearance with a nice off-white head. Very funky, big barnyard, tart lemon, cobweb, very earthy/herbal, citrusy, complex aroma. Quite puckering, very funky, tart lemon citrusy, barnyard, straw, a bit grassy, somewhat dusty flavor. It finishes fairly puckering, dry, and lemon. Really good and refreshing.

Poured into a tulip. This is my official "end of first year of med school celebrating beer." 2007 vintage, bottled 12/27/2007 and given a 10 year lifespan. 

5.0 A: Mildly hazed light orange color. Three fingers of frothy white head. Retention is very good and thick, glass covering lacing is left behind.

4.5 S: Really nice nose on this as well. The funk is amazing. This might be the most powerful and complex funk Ive ever encountered. Tons of hay and horse. Decaying fruit, stinky sweaty feet, apple orchard, dry rotted sweat socks, old wood. Like most other 3F gueuzes, this is insanely complex with the funk, but not all that sour. Nearly no acetic acid and only mild amounts of lactic acid. Borderline 5.0.

4.0 T: Taste is good, but its not as complex or as overall good as the nose. Theres more sourness, but its a strange dry sourness, which is something Ive never experienced before. Other than that, the funk is still crazy strong, but not quite as complex. Lots of hay, dry earthy woodiness, dry rotted sweat socks, musty basement. Lightly horsey. Mild lemony fruitiness.

3.5 M: Lighter body. Good spritzy gueuzy carbonation. Could use more creaminess though.

4.0 D: This is good and I appreciate the funk, but its a tad bit disappointing, especially given how impressive the nose is. Dont get me wrong, its still a great gueuze, but I expect a lot from 3F when it comes to them.

Rating #3000.  Wanted to get something good, and heard this was drinking the best right now.  2004 vintage, 375 mL bottle.  Cork was a bitch, but got it out eventually.  Nice hazy orange-red pour with fluffy white head, somehow it sticks around and has nice lacing, gorgeous looking beer. A - Pours slightly hazy copper orange with a fluffy one finger tall white head leaving small streaks of lace down the glass.

S - Smells of lots of horse blanket funk, damp earth, granny smith apples, lemon, basement must and a good amount of oak. While it possesses quite a bit of funk, it never gets too overpowering.

T - Starts off with a decent sour kick initially quickly being enveloped by the strong barnyard funk, musty earth, fruit and a touch of sweetness. Finish has plenty of oak tannins, combining with a little leftover funk, to leave the pallet dried but craving more.

M - Light body with tart, crisp feel and moderate carbonation. This one has very nice balance, as most drie fonteinens do, and it was very easy to drink.

O - I have now had nearly all of the gueuzes from drie fonteinen and I can definitely see why people go crazy over them. They are crisp and flavorful while remaining easy to drink. Not my favorite of the bunch but no slouch either.

The 2007 Vintage Oude Gueuze pours a cloudy tangerine color with a golden border and a champagne color right at the edge of the glass. A small creamy white head forms initially.

This is a tightly wound aroma of fruit and sour notes. Nice horse blanket funkiness. Tart apples, sour white grapes, and a little woodiness as well.

2002-2007 Vertical, split amongst good friends at our engagement part. Bottles provided by Alex, Jason, and myself. 375ml and 750ml bottles for the various years.

I would rank them in the following order: 2003, 2002, 2005 (Feb), 2007, 2005 (Dec), 2004, and 2006 (bad bottle, I think).

*I am going to rate into one but not going to include the 2006, because it was so damn bad, and would really hurt the overall score.

A - All pour a very similar mirky/hazy golden yellow, fizzy white head, some spotty lacing, bubbles here and there on top. Some had more carbonation then others, but overall, all very similar (and no gushers).

S - Funk, sour/tart notes, lactic notes, lemon peels, barnyard. Most of the vintages were restrained in lip-puckering funk/sour/tart, dont get me wrong, it was there, but not as evident as other 3F sours. I enjoyed this characteristic, truthfully.

T - More sour/tart notes then funk, but a good balance of everything. Nice barnyard, sour funky acidic notes, lemon peel citrus, orange peel, slight touch of oak. Some years were more funky then others, but this is what I tasted overall.

M - Light, crisp, fizzy champagne-esk carbonation, dry finish.

D - It was wonderful to drink 2002-2007 at one time and really makes you appreciate all the various years and maturity/aging. The winner for me was 2003 but it would be near impossible to pick any year (besides 2006) blind. 

Thanks to Jason and Alex for helping make this happen. I really appreciate it and it was a fun part of the celebration (although those non-BAs thought we were crazy...haha).

Notes of lemon, white grapes, barnyard funk, oak, lactic acid, cedar, green apple skins, and pears. Medium-bodied, with a really satisfying tart mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Dry finish. Awesome and tart. Really liked it. Re-Rate, 2002 Vintage from STLWills 30th birthday party. Pours a hazy straw gold with a small bone white head. The aroma is earthy, grassy, funky, and herbal; the flavor is more sour, lemony, and oaky, with some nice funk, too. Medium-bodied, surprisingly earthy. Re-Rate: Well, Im not going to change the rating because its probably not fair. But I tried a 2002 and 2006 Vintage right next to each other. The 2002 would be about a 3.7 at this point; really dusty and musty and funky, and pretty satisfying. The 2006 is garbage juice right now, though. One of the grossest beers Ive had lately. So if you have one, trade it to some sap who will give you some better, fresher beer for it.

2005, Belgian release. Thanks Kenny for sharing this one. Pours a cloudy amber-orange with a thin, fine off-white head. Aroma bursts from the glass with sweet-tart fruitiness followed by a strong barnyard pungency. Multi-layered, nose-tickling acidity surrounds spicy, and earthy complexities. Flavor follows from the aroma with a taste bud cramping sour profile and wonderfully dirty animal characteristics. Light, nimble body with a ton of depth Dry spiciness extends into tho long finish.

Aroma: sour, wild
Appearance: dark amber
Taste: sour, well balanced.
Palate: medium body
Overall:19/20

Aroma: Apples, marsipan, apple cider, apple cider vinegar, apple maps, lime and sulfur.
Taste: Fresh apples, apple maps, carneval apples, marsipan, apple pie, lime and some wood notes.
Mouthfeel: A sourness that coates the whole mouth, crisp and quite light.

This poured a semi cloudy straw yellow color with a white head. Aroma was lots of funky lemons, bretty, grainy and yeasty, some peaches too. Flavor was a bit more dry than expected, very tart and funky, some lemons but taste does not last very long.

2006 vintage.

Beer is yellow and mostly clear until the bottom. Its effervescent. White head of medium and small bubbles that doesnt leave much lacing on the glass or hang out very long. Looks good.

"This beer smells like a nuns crotch" - Lunch (he meant it as a good thing)

Aroma is nice and bright with acetic sourness, mild citrus fruit bitterness and some mild lactic notes. There isnt much oak in here, perhaps with age it would get better. I am loving the mild funk on the back end of the aroma though. Its complex, poster child for a great smelling gueuze.

Beer is light and has a lot of carbon in the mouth. Its tart and sour but leads with the sour palate and the tartness is minimal. The acetic is winning I feel in here with a healthy brettish funk on the back end. There is a strong citric character as well. Its semi-fruity if that makes sense. I love the palate connectivity of this gueuze, I wonder what this would be like in 10 years. Its complex and simple simultaneously and I love this beer. Some were underwhelmed by it but its close to perfect as a gueuze can be IMO. I love this beer.

Serving type: bottle

4-13 tasting at Weisguys. 750ml bottle from 30/11/2006. A solid pour produces a small, incredibly cloudy white head. Color is typical dark, hazey orange geuze. Smell is sweet, funky cheese as well as hay and dry lemon rind. In the taste I pick up tart lemon and lime then in a second layer some nice funk and cheese with some fruity acidic kumquat in the finish. Mouthfeel is slick with mild carbonation. I cant wait to try more vintages of this!

UPDATED: DEC 23, 2015 2004 Vintage. First half of bottle pours clear, second half semi hazy as the yeast enters the mix. Head lasts a while.. Aromas of dough and dried abricots as well as the usual farmyardy qualities. The taste is pretty mineral with controled sweetnes. The sour notes are big here with lots of mineral, zesty, lemony notes that continue well into the aftertaste. A refreshing and well balanced geuze is my verdict.  
2010 vintage - still overly elegant. Liked it even better second time around. Hiking the score a bit but could really have gone even higher, but lets not get sentimental.

Golden coloured and hazy. Has a white head, medium duration. Aroma is acidic, complex.  Sulfur notes. Fresh, clear aroma. Acidic flavor, sweetness too, strong, faint sulfur. Dry texture, a bit astringent.
nice saur aroma,amber, hazy, white foam, medium sourness, salty, medium body, creamy, soft carbonation, longnice soft sour finish finish,
Bottle 2004. Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Yellow colour. Powerfull sour great aroma. Moderate bitter exstremely sour flavor. Long finish. Oily palate.
Shared bottle courtesy of tarjei. Tanned head on a murky golden body. Apples, berries, malts and pears in the aroma. Acidic with notes of malts and grapeffruit. Medium to full body. Light dry.

05-MAY-2011, bottle @Mikkeller Bar, shared by Faroeviking.
Vintage 2002.
Pours cloudy light golden.
Lovely grapey nose.
Taste is fantastic. OK, it does have some barnyard notes, but mostly grapey fruity tones.
It is sour but has so much mellowed out all sharp features including the sourness leaving only a slight tartness, and a long fine taste with a wonderfull full body.
Thansk for sharing:-)

375ml, red label, 2005 vintage received as an extra from PALMEJ1! Thanks a ton Jacob! You are a madman.

Pours a cloudy, very dark golden range color golden tangerine/burnt orange hues when held to a light and a one finger frothy white head that slowly fades into a lasting ring. Sporadic spots of lacing left behind.

Funky, earthy aroma with a heavy barnyard/horsey presence that is countered by crisp light fruit and sweet vinegar. Subtle lactic presence. A bunch of earthy oak along with the funky bugs as well as some grassy straw, cobwebs and musty funk. Hints of apple, pear, grape and tangerine. Extremely complex nose that has my mouth watering. I literally smelled this beer for ten minutes before taking the first sip.

Medium bodied yet fuller than expected with an intensely sour, mouth-puckering flavor that lingers throughout into a sweet, slightly acidic, vinegary tart finish. Very dry and tart up front with only slight acidity in the finish. No solvent or harsh acetic character at all. Extremely funky with lots of earthy oak tannins, bugs and a touch of vinaigrette which is balanced by a slight lactic presence as well as some light fruit. Hints of apple, pear and lemon combined with the vinegar character give this beer a sweet and tart lingering finish that leaves me drooling for another sip. After the initial palate shock this beer proves to be incredibly complex, well balanced and flavorful.

Overall, I had very high expectations for this beer and they were exceeded. With all of its complexity it is still incredibly quaffable. I absolutely loved this beer and hope to get another bottle sometime.
2006 vintage. Murky orange. Funky aroma, sour taste but also a little bit sweet. Manages to both be a little rough and have great drinkability.

Vertical drank for Sean and Carolines engagement party, quite a shame other Chicago Bas couldnt make it for this one, great times. This is the type of beer that just screams to have separate vintage listings as there was such variation. Instead of reviewing each one, this will more be a guide for those interested in the different vintages.
2002 Vintage 750 ml bottle - one of the top 3 vintages of the night. Awesome aroma that was funky but not harsh, wonderful dusty farmyard notes. The taste was just special because it was biting, dusty, floral and sour, yet it wasnt Cantillon sour in that I could drink this all night long. A vintage worth trying.
2003 Vintage 375 ml bottle - This was pretty decent, in the middle of the variations. Was drank simultaneously with an 03 Drie Oude Gueuze and the Vintage destroyed it. Not even in the same galaxy.
2004 Vintage 375 ml bottle - Nothing really stood out here, still good but towards the bottom.
2005 Vintage 375 ml bottle - Somehow this vintage has two bottle dates, a shocking 10 months apart, February 2005 and December 2005. The older one was much better and was in the top 3.
2006 Vintage 750 ml bottle - Hands down the worst of the bunch, Im almost positive this had to be a bad bottle. This was totally malty, tons of caramel and dough with hops, was like a gueuze barleywine. Terrible, I would not drink this again.
2007 Vintage 750 ml bottle - Valentines dating. To me this was the best of the bunch, a little more sour and acidic which I like in my gueuze. Very musky, just wonderful overall. I picked this up at Drie, super happy I have one left.

Thanks to Alex and Sean for contributing to this.
Bottle...  Poured hazy golden orangish with a white head.  Musky, cardboard aroma.  Some light fruits like plums and apricots.  Attic dust, and lots of horse blanket with a souring finish.

75cl bottle (dated 17/12/07) from White Horse, Parsons Green. It pours a golden yellow colour with moderate carbonation and a large foamy white head. The nose is farmyard, grape, lemon, lime, grapefruit and even some sour tomato. The taste is dominantly tart: lots of lime, lemon rind, grape, redcurrants, grapefruit and granny smith apples, which mellows out to slightly sweeter notes of red apples and pears. Its complex, very well balanced and smooth. Absolutely brilliant stuff and one of the best beers Ive tasted.

Pours hazy orange with a big head.
Aroma of apples and hay.
Taste of peaches and apple juice, rather big bodied.

Flaske: Orangegul uklar øl uden skumhoved, og meget svag karbonering. Tilgengæld er den klassisk geuze dog mindre sur og mere balanceret end normalen. Virkelig en treat og dejlig dejlig øl. Årgang 2006.

Bottle. Pours hazy orange, quite big white head. Sweet and sour nose. Lots of currant seeds kind of notes. Lots of gooseberry notes in taste. Big taste, but I kind of prefer the more straight forward sour/fruity lambics. This is almost too much for me. Ends in a bitter blood orange way.

2002 vintage. Pours a gold with a small white head. Smell: Sour, funky with oak and hay (grass). Taste is acidic,  grassy and notes of wood, tart and dry finish. I have quite regular access to this beer, and I have to say that the 2002 vintage is one on its own, fantastic!!

Tämä köössin väri on samea amber. Valkoista vaahtoa muodostuu kohtuullisesti. Todella hedelmäinen, maanläheinen, purkkahiivainen ja sammaleinen tuoksu. Maku on hiivainen, ja kirpeän hedelmäinen. Hapan, kirpeä ja maanläheinen olut.

Bottle Vintage 2004, bottled 09/04/2004. Pours a clear almost amber with thin white head. Aroma is sour oak, cork, basement, bread, vinegar. Taste is heavy sour, very light bitter. Medium body, thin, soft carbonation, lasting astringent finish.

2006 "Vintage" opened by drabmuh at a recent tasting.

Pours a hazy golden color with a nice white head and a fair amount of lacing on the way down. The nose smacked me right away with a really pungent horse blanket odor; loads of leather and must. A bit of hay and some slightly sour notes come through as well.

The taste brings on even more funk--its like the sweat of wet leather thats been in a hay loft for the past four years. Just crazy funky. A bit of oak is present as well. Mouthfeel is nice and light to medium with good carbonation, really bringing the flavors through the full palate. Drinkability is pretty good, although as good as this tasted, I didnt immediately feel like I needed more after Id finished my pour.

Serving type: bottle

Reviewed on: 10-06-2010

2002 bottle at Mes Tasting. Pours a cloudy gold with a mild, white cream head. Sour, acidic aroma with oak and grass. Lightly sweet, woody, super acidic, with notes of grass and hay. Light to medium in body with effervescent carbonation. Tart, clean finish, dry, oaky, grassy. Beautiful beer.

Bottle 375ml. Bottled 09/04/2004
Pours cloudy golden on a light thin white head. 
Aroma of apples and general fruits. 
Taste of oak a fruits, bitter and a very good Geuze experience for a novice Lambic, thanks for a wonderful beer.

Vintage 2004
Smell: New, fresh, dried oak.
Taste: Crisp winter apples and oak
Aftertaste: A bit bitter after taste - a nice geueze but a shame
with the aftertaste.

Bottle thx to Hjalmar, cons 2011-01-08 Göteborg
AR: sourness, like a ordinary Geuze, autum fruits, almond beskvier (wee cookies)
AP: appel juice - hazy, light cider foam
F: appel cider vinaeger, bitter, bitter, rubarab
Yolk: same but more nuttiness

2002 Bottle shared by Paul, at after tasting to saison tasting.Thanks again. Orange pour with some white lacing of head. Huge brett aroma, funky leather, some light wood, earthy tones, and light fruit. Funky and enjoyable flavor, wish I could session this brew.
(rating #1199, aka 1200(a))
Color ambrato arancione senza schiuma. Aroma decisamente nello stile, ma molto intrigante. In bocca è splendida con finale lungo e appagante.

Bottle, vintage 2004. 

Hazy golden with a brief, small white head. Pleasant sour aroma of apples, grass, wood and barnyard. The taste had the same and also grape and dust. A lot of carbonation. Very drinkable and dry.

UPDATED: DEC 30, 2010 750ml Bottle (2007 Vintage, Vintage St. Valentijn Cuvée.  Bottled 2/14/07):  Very tart aroma of wood, gueuze, acid, leather, oak, and slight fruit.  Poured orange/amber in color with a small to medium-sized, creamy, dense, rocky, off-white head that diminished but lasted throughout.  Cloudy.  Very sparkling.  Very good lacing.  Flavor is heavily tart and medium sweet.  Tastes of oak, wood, light fruit, acid, sugar, and leather.  Medium body.  Dry texture.  Average to lively carbonation.  Wood, oak, tart fruit, acid, leather, and light fruit finish is medium sweet, heavily tart, and dry.  Delicious.

Red labeled 750 bottle.from the 2002 vintage. Shared with my brewer brother along with some killer chili. Pops opens nicely and pours a hazy yellow with a bright white head. Very nice nose - straight up horsey funk and lemon zest. Citrus blast of lemon and grapefruit on the tongue followed with some bready yeasts. Nicely tart for its age. Yummy stuff. Finishes quite dry with tingly carbonation. Thanks to RJ for this bomber....
Very nice, mellow balanced tasted. Standard lambic flavors, but without any of the harshness. Smooth mouthfeel, slight carbonation at the end. Dark amber color with no head.
Pours a golden orange with a small white head. Aromas of sweet fruit, citrus and some barnyard. The taste is sweet and dry. Amazing sour.

2002 bottle. Lambics always remind me of minge for some reason. Orange with thin to no head. Aroma of awesome sweetness. Flavour has citrus notes with a smooth tongue dancing freshness. Mouthfeel is superb. Not a style I know a lot about (do I know any style?) but this is hitting the parts other beers can not reach. Carlsberg can kiss my big old hairy bean bag. Lovely stuff.

375ml corked bottle.  Small carbonation pop.   Murky orange-tan.  Thin, soda-like head.  Sweet barnyard funk aroma.  Some orange, tangerine, lemon, lime notes.  Has mellowed a little bit, but still has some pleasant tartness.  Wheaty and dry, with some malt smoothness in the backbone.  Quite an awesome beer.

UPDATED: DEC 10, 2012 2005 vintage. Drinking to celebrate 10 weeks without cigarettes. Pours clear caramel head with a but of head, but it fades to nothing within seconds. Aroma has a lot of funky and wild yeast, barnyard smells, leather, wood, freshly picked granny smith, delicious oaky vanilla sweetness. A bit of straw, hay. Some sweet yeast and grain components in the far back. Just so balanced. Taste is beautifully balanced as well. Distinct tartness, lemony, citric tartness held back by subtle oak qualities, apples and grape. This tastes rather fruity around the tartness and wild yeast. This is the most elegant gueuze to encounter my taste buds this far.  Vintage 2002 re-rate  Nose is marked with the 10 years of age. Basement, band aids, worn oak, attic, yard sale, old leather, moving on to grapefruit, melon, ashes, candy floss. I hate myself for writing shit like this. Tastes like lemon juice, lemonade, less complex and ashy than the nose, not the same sulphury note as the nose. Good buzz @13.99

UPDATED: NOV 20, 2010 06 bottle.  Golden, hazy orange in the glass.  Aroma is musty, funk, cheese rind, tart, and buried sour.  Smells amazing.  Taste is rounded funk, tart, dry must, and some prickly sour.  Back 1/3 of the taste a bit watery.  Even with the lackluster carbonation in this bottle the beer was still excellent.

Bottle, vintage 2005. Cloudy orange/amber, with a mall small to non existant white head. Citrus, barnyard, wet socks, sourness and some fruit in both the aroma and taste. Low carbonation. A bit more watery on the palate than the 2002 bottle I tried a while back. This one is good, but the 2002 was awesome.
Bottle.Vintage 30/11 2006.Dark muddy orange colour.Aroma of wood barnyard and mild acid,still with some fresh apple flavor and good dry mouthfeels to finish off.

Flaske 0,75l. Lys gylden. Aprikosfarget. Høyt luftig skum som varer en stund. Litt uklart. Syrlig aroma med litt pepper. Smaken er som forventet: Syrlig med variasjoner av frukt. Litt tørr bitter ettersmak. Mer interessant enn god. Ser fram til Tour de Geuze neste år for å (forhåpentligvis) bli mer dus med sorten.

Yes, it says "vintage" on the label, Bottled April 12 2005. Poured into a Gueuze glass, has a modest amount of head and a yellow body with a fair amount of carbonation. Heavy aroma of sour gueuze, lemon, citrus. Taste is a soft mix of wood, lemon, cardboard in a good way. Very light, not heavy. Lacks complexity and could be softer given its been aging for five years. I had high expectations that werent met, but its still a decent gueuze.
Bottle of the 2005.  Very leathery, funky aroma.  Medium sour flavor is quite funky and sweat sock-like layered over the lemony acidity.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2010 Bottle. 2002 vinatage with the red label. Pours a slightly hazed straw color with a nice white head thy is quick to settle. Nice aroma although a little subtle and clean with hints of barnyard and earth.  Citrus type aromas like grapefruit. Sour and tart smelling. Very clean tasting with a slight touch of medicinal undertones. Amazing stuff. Grapefruit with touches of tartness. Dry overall. Lemon zest with a slight touch of bitterness like tannins in wine. Light mouthfeel with good carbonation.

750ml bottle thanks to largerdeer, vintage 2007.  Pours a hazy golden color with a small white head that leaves a ring.  The aroma is great - typical 3F - very funky with horseblanket and pigsheet and lots of oak -bal.  Flavor is excellent.  Funky horsey cowy barnyard, pale malt base, oaky musty -bals, and a great tart finish.  Medium-bodied and very smooth with lots of acidity on the finish.  Really solid brewski overall - I could have twoski.
Bottle at SBWF 2010 (Brill). It poured a hazy golden liquid. Sweet and acidic frutiy flavour. It has that nice sourness that I enjoy so much. Powerfull and complex beer. Very nice!

Bottle Vintage 2005. Hazy golden body with a steady creamy off white head. The aroma is barnyard, acid, hops, sour grapes and wood. The flavour is sulfur, barnyard, light hay, citrus, acid, very dry brett and grape fruit. Loads of grape fruit and dust in the finish. Lovely!

750 ml bottle from De Heeren van Liedekerke vintage 2004 sold in 2007. Pours a cloudy yellow/orange color with a large white head. Very sour notes of wood and yeast. The flavor is sour and lively; very sour and tannic, some floral petals, not much sweetness, green apples and funky flavors. Nice.
Bottle. Pours unclear orangey amber with a white head. Dry bretty and sour aroma. The flavor is bretty funky, like rhubarb almost, with a nice amount of tartness. Nice.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2012 2002 yellow label 375ml served at Bier Circus in Bruxelles on August 13 2010.
A: Bright straw colored body with a large white cap.  Spotty lacing after a few minutes of slow destruction of the head.
S: Nice lactic tartness.  Bright lemon citric notes.  Musty oak and a nice wet horse blanket funk.
T: While the nose was quite inviting, the flavor profile just didnt match up.  The flavors were a bit muddled and muted.  The beer tartness was soft and the flavors never really popped.  Age might of been a factor here.
M: Moderate carbonation.  Medium body.  Nice dry finish.  A bit muddled throughout.
O: A good qeuze, but not quite deserving of the special labeling.  As noted above,  age might of been a factor.

UPDATED: APR 13, 2016 2003 375 ml yellow bottle. Purchased at the brewery in 2007. Popped open with just the lightest fizz. This one has to be close to flat. Aggressive 1/2 bottle pour confirms that.  This one is very clear, bright light copper color. No head. Nose is supremely tart, a bit of citrus, paint thinner. Taste starts off as dry as the Sahara, with the flavors not nearly as pungent and aggressive as the aroma hints at.  The extreme flavors have tapered off through the years leaving this a mellow brew. Still a nice tartness on the end but not the tonsil burning tanginess Ive had from some of their other gueze beers. Overall good. Ive got another bottle-hope there is some carbonation in that one. 5/4/13: 02 bottle thanks to Matt. Musty, oaky. Really a beautiful beer.  4.6
user_location: Seattle still not near Beersel., Washington, USA

text:
375ml bottle, 2002 vintage, red label from Bier Circus.
Appearance : Clear amber with a big creamy head that fades away fast.  Nice color !

Aroma : Slightly dusty with some wood and apples. Some tartness and a light sweetness. Feels humid.

Taste : Woody and sour. Slightly acidic.  Nice green apples notes. Finish quite dry and woody. Light funk and light barnyard.

Overall : Gets better as Im drinking it. Quite drinkable. Could be more funky but still very good. Not sure if its better than the regular gueuze. I think this one is more woody. Very nice beer.

2002 vintage, red label. Undoubtedly one of the most balanced and perfect lambics I have ever encountered. Tart fruitiness, acidity, and dryness are expertly weighed against each other to create a sour beer that captures the essence of gueuze-- The perfect combination. Amazing stuff.

UPDATED: APR 19, 2012 2002 bottle courtesy of Craftycarl21. One of the best, most balanced example of geuze out there. Excellent funk profile that is constituted of the perfect quantities of must, dry nectar fruits, hay, and acid. The palate is truely epic- so dry and crisp. Thanks Carl.

(bottle, 37.5cl, vintage 2002) Cloudy, deep orange to golden colour with a big but collapsing slightly off-white frothy head. Acidic fruity aroma of apples, citrus and distinctive notes of barnyard and a woody touch. Moderately sour flavour with a tinge of bitterness, medium to light bodied. Dry and fruity Lambic character with notes of barnyard/Brett; lingering sour-fruity and bitter-tart finish with a tannic aftertaste. Superb. 13.VII.10

2002 Bottle Brought by CraftyCarl and shared at Ebenezers
Light Golden pour, Aroma is subtle lemongrass, sour, delightul must, and light grass and hay.  Ultimately blended and aged to achieve maybe the most balanced geuzes out there,  wonderfully sour and dry with a savory deliciousness. Simply stunning.

Bottle at home after a great day at GBBF. Stunning Geuze. vintage 2005. Luminous hazy orange. Thick fine head. Nose of green apples, green tangerines and fresh gooseberries. Devine. Perfectly balanced palate. Not too sour, not too lactic, fruity and fresh. Light prickly mouthfeel, and just great. Bathtub stuff once again!!!

Bottle (vintage 2002): Hazy, orangey coloured, slowly collapsing loose white head; green apples, vinegar and some wood in the cellary nose; solid dry sourish-sweet flavour with a distinctive bitterness, medium bodied and incredible - quite soft; bretty sour fruity and wheaty finish with a distinctive tartness and bitterness in the aftertaste. Very good and relatively well rounded....

UPDATED: SEP 10, 2010 Bottle: Vintage 2005:
Nice 3 finger white foamy head, disappears quick.
Clear dark orange color.
Smell is a dominating mix of sour and wood.
First taste is a fresh taste with hints of sour, fruit (lemon, lime, citrus), wood, yeast and dust.
Aftertaste is more bitter with still a good amount of sour with fruit and yeast. Long lasting taste.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Vintage 2005. Hazy orange colour with a disappearing small white head. Aroma is barnyard, vinegar and citrus. Flavour is grapefruit, lemon, acid and apples. Medium-bodied, aftertaste is acidic and dry.

Vintage 2005.

Is this geuze? It pours the color of the setting sun and smells like a bowl of tropical fruit. Tangerines, grapefruit, nectarines.. this could be an IPA were it not for the acidity.

And there is plenty of that. Its dry and sour, with carbonation that is borderline effervescent. The CO2 is what I dont like about Drie Fonteinens standard Oude Geuze, but in this case its just right; more sparkling than spritzy.

After two 375 ml bottles I can say with confidence that yes, this is geuze alright.
user_location: The Court of the Crimson King, California, USA

text: UPDATED: FEB 13, 2014 First rating37.5 cl bottle at Dahlbergs, Helsingborg. From 09/04/2004. BB 02/2014. Sampled on July 23, 2010Cloudy orange color, white head. Acidic, citrus, stable scent. Acidic, sour, unripe apples, stable taste. Medium a bit puckering moutheel, low bitterness.8/3/8/3/15=3.7Rerate750 ml bottle on January 8, 2011. BB 11/2016Thanks to Hjalmar! (non ratebeer).Cloudy orange color, smallish whte head. Mix of sweet and sour scent. Acidic taste. Smooth mouthfeel, very low bitterness.7/3/7/4/14=3.5Rerate75 cl bottle at Rotary Pub, Göteborg, sampled on October 26, 2012.Label state Lot 30/11/2006, BB 11/2016.Hazy golden color, very small white head. Sweet, honey (how the hell!??), acidic, sour scent. Acidic, metallic, sour, hints of sweetness taste. Medium mouthfeel, very low bitterness. Tart finish.7/3/8/3/15=3.6

A: The pour is a cloudy bright copper color with tons of white head and a nice lacing on the glass.

S: Just a ton of wonderful funk hits the nose as soon as the cork is popped. Lots of barnyard, wet hay, and a bit of sweat. There is plenty of green apple and lemon to provide tartness as well.

T: The flavor is just so typical of Drie Fonteinen lambic. Lots of pungent and intense funk flavors followed by a sharp and crisp lactic acidity. A nice green apple tartness and some lemons in there as well.

M: The body is medium with plentiful but not overwhelming carbonation.

D: This is just another exceptional gueuze from Drie Fonteinen. Im happy to have tried this and would gladly drink this, or any of their other beers, again.

UPDATED: JUL 12, 2010 This is the business. This gueuze is outstanding. Bottled - 10th February 2005.  Bottle, bought from Beermerchants. Poured into a goblet glass as I dont have a 3 Fonteinen glass yet which is criminal. Poured slowly. Lovely golden red colour. Acid and tart hit the tongue; cherries, apples (the texture reminds me of apples for some reason), funky elements, this is a hell of a gueuze. One of the greats. Screw it. Im giving it a five. This one is for the World Cup final because it is a genuine WORLD CLASS BEER. BLINDING.

UPDATED: JUL 29, 2012 Bottle, 37.5cl, from trade with jbrus. Vintage 2003. It was a pita to open this one. First there were two cages, the outer sort of twisted into the other one. Then it was quite difficult to pop the cork, one of the worst Ive ever experienced. But it was worth it. It pours a hazy, lively bright orange body with a creamy off-white head taking ages to settle. The aroma has lots of funky, citrusy barnyard aromas, with something peppery in the far back. A little alcohol too it seems. Its tart, refreshing, effervescent and medium bodied, with flavors of lemon, pale malts and funk. Towards the end it has a certain touch of black pepper, quite subtle, but sure present. The finish is lasting, dry and puckering, with lemon and some black pepper hints. A really wonderful thirst quencher, and equally wonderful in your favorite chair with or with some cheese snack. Rating: 8-5-8-4-16-4.1. 100707Bottle, 375ml corked. 2004 vintage, with the same label as Oude Geuze 1998 (50th Anniversary). Thanks a lot for sharing OleR. Its an unclear, orange colored beer with a thin, off-white head. Wonderful funky, lemony aroma. Barnyard, earth, old leather, some wood. Lick entering a stable and sticking your nose into and old saddle, with the added joy of a pleasant fruityness. Hay too, layers and layers of aromas building up, Smooth, dry and tart, nicely carbonated. As the aroma, the flavor is just wonderful and complex. Both balanced and incredibly, incredibly tasteful. Lemon, barnyard, leather, something reminiscent of American hops, and with a woody touch. Lasting sourness, with a lot of funky balance. Damn, this is just plain, gorgeous pleasure. Probably as close to perfection I will ever have. Thx a lot my friend, for sharing this one. 111014

750ml dark green bottle topped by  a cork and a wire cradle. Bottled date: 14.02.2007. Bought at Vinmonopolet Langnes Tromsø. Copper coloured body with a slight haze. Circular edge surrounding the rim of the glass. Smell of acid citrus fruits, mellow cheese and old books. Pronounced tartness of grapefruits in flavour along with notes of apples, honey sweetness, dry cheese and yeast. Super dry on the swallow. Not bad, but drinking geuze is still an ongoing educational experience for me. (Tromsø, 03.07.2010)

750mL, bottled March 13, 2002.  Rated July 2nd, 2010.  Many, many props to my friend Kyle for shipping a case of this to me from Switzerland.  The cork pops off as soon as the cage is loosened, but it doesnt gush or foam up.  Pours a hazy orange amber with a big white head.   Aroma is beautiful, tons of musty sour funk, with barnyard, citrus peel and dust.  Initial flavor is a touch dull and oxidized, but quickly blossoms into a bouquet of lemon and grapefruit peel, without the bitterness or astringency.  Lots of funk, barnyard, sourness.  Finish is funky grapefruit peel, with only a trace of bitterness.  Sublime.

2002 Vintage.  For an 8 year old bottle, it has a surprising amount of carbonation.  The cap popped out of the bottle after loosening the cage.  Hazy orange-yellow pour.  Good white head.  Incredibly funky aroma.  Lots of barnyard, earth, wood, and sweat.  Some lemon citrus.  The flavor really surprised.  Theres almost a bit of sweetness as the beer hits the tongue.  The slight sweetness gives way to bitter lemon peel.  Incredible dusty and funky.  Good amount of sourness, though not overpowering or harsh.  Finish has touches of oak.  Incredibly delicious, unique, and interesting beer.
bottle - slight hazy orange brownish beer with a thin off-white head. Aroma has a lot of fruits and vinegar. Flavour is sour but also bitter, prominent oak hints. Medium to low carbonation.

[bottle]
Complex aroma of sour fruit, white grape, and subtle vanilla and butterscotch oak. Hazy yellow-orange under an off-white cover. Flavour begins with mouth-puckering sourness, but nicely develops into fresh tropical fruit and woody bitterness and then the oaky characteristics come out in the finish-butterscotch/vanilla. Light body, medium to high carbonation, dry oaky finish.

Bottle of the 2005 special edition one at Pauls saison tasting.  Pours a hazy brown with a thin white head .  Gorgeous sweet funk and sour notes. Medium bodied, cheesy and funky, 	nice tart notes, big funk.  Finishes up with more slow lingering funk, a nice tartness.  Gorgeous.

Bottle.

A - Golden, brassy orange color with an average sized, foamy, and bubbly white head with a bit below average retention and a thin bubbly lace left.

S - Well balanced hay/barnyard/funk along with some lemon citrus and apple. Has a good juicy aroma along with a touch of a tart and acidic aroma. Perfect balance between the aroma, my mouth is watering and it is very enticing.

T - Similar to the nose. Some funk and tartness with just a hint of sour taste. A lot of fruitiness with some apple and lemon being strongest. Hints of other golden and tropical fruit as well as some earthiness. Some hay and mustiness and a touch of lemongrass. Very well balanced sour.

M - Medium body with a healthy amount of carbonation. Fairly smooth with a drying finish and just the very slightest bit of puckering.

D - Well balanced and not overly sour/tart but has a nice balance.

Notes: Bottled 10/02/2005. A wonderful gueuze that is very well balanced with the tart/sour/funky flavor and a juicy fruitiness. Easy to drink and a joy to drink as well. Definitely recommend this.

375 ml corked bottle. A hazy pale amber beer with an average sized, frothy/fizzy, mostly lasting white head. The aroma is lightly malty and moderately yeasty, with notes of barnyard, lemon, wood, sour apple, some cheese and basement aromas too. Really funky and great. The flavour is lightly to moderately sweet, moderately to heavily sour, lightly bitter. Well balanced, with just the necessary sweetness. Medium body, lively carbonation, dry long finish with light bitterness. Probably the lambic with the most mixture of complexity, drinkabilty and quenching charcteristics Ive tasted so far. Really amazing.

Sampled at the DC Epic Sour Tasting 2010.  2002 Vintage.  Pours a hazy, burnt orange with a very frothy, white head.  Nose is white pepper, celery, herbs, brett, grass, funk, hay, spices, band aid, vegetables like fresh cabbage.  Flavor is well balanced, sweet, lemons, brett, kumquat, white pepper, celery, grass, hay, orange rind.  Finish is dry, tart and dusty.  Exceptional.

2002 Vintage

A-pours a transparent golden amber color with tons of bubbles, fluffy and bubbly white head with good retention and a spotty lace.

UPDATED: APR 20, 2011 Had the oude geuze vintage (yellow label) and the oude geuze vintage special edition (red label) both from 2002 thanks to Todd and GT.  This was a blind test and the red label came out on top.  appearance was cloudy golden that left decent lacing.  Much sour tartness coming in on the nose.  Taste is dry, sour, but not overpowering. Since my original rating, I have had this beer probably 5-6 more times and it just gets better every time.  I recently drank an 02 red label, and the subtle blend of black and white pepper, leathery funk, and an absolutely perfect mouthfeel lead me to re-rate this brew higher.  The aroma is one I would put right behind Roos. Light lemony funk, leather, peppery, and soft.  Just beautiful

2005 - 375mL.        

A - pours a hazy almost burnt orange with a full inch of fluffy off white head that recedes to an everlasting sheet with moderate lacing.

S - hay, lemon, apples, band-aids, and all the lovely smells that make a perfect gueuze.

T - the acidity has slacked off and made this perfectly balanced. a glass of funk with a touch of citric/lactic acid that doesnt fatigue the palate at all.

M/D - the carbonation and finish are spot on and have me going back for another sip before I can even sit the beer down. A standard that most gueuze should be held to.

(Bottle - Vintage 2005)
Nice finger and a half slightly frothy off-white head, with a light copper burnt orange color; slightly hazy.  Leather and minerals show first in the aroma; sharp acidity; orangey citrus; faint whiff of cream cheese.  Just packed full of flavor: a sharpness at first that is quick to mellow out over the palate; acidic sourness thats akin to sourdough; some woodiness; leather; a bit of funk...just runs the gamut.  Lively, vibrant carbonation with a bone-dry finish.  Nice complexity, and awesome to drink.

Vintage 2007. Enjoyed from a 0.75L corked bottle, bought at Vinmonopolet.  Tall(!) big-bubbled white head.  Body is well carbonated, hazy, orange/gold colored.  Tangy and acidic fruit aroma; green apples, unripe berries and extracted lemon juice. Notes of horse-stable, mould and crisp wheaty malts. Taste is dry and fruity-acidic with some sweet undertones. Surprisingly mellow, without any dominating Bretty notes, actually. Well-bodied for the style. Not as mouth-cleansing as expected. Overall a highly drinkable and easy-to-like Geuze.
Bottled 375ml. Ordered from www.bierkompasss.de. Extremely nice throughout.
Thanks to GodoThunder. Hazy light brown pour. Stinky feet, tart, dusty acidic aroma. Taste is sour bite, lemon, dry, dusty and very light. Real easy to drink, awesome.

Bottle, purchased at Bier Temple, Brussels.  Pours a cloudy yellow.  Funky and tart aroma with a lot of acidity.  Really bites going down.  Great sourness and acidity.  Bittler lemons and dirty socks.  Great gueze.  One of the best Ive ever had.

aroma is very funky, with horses, biting limes, and a woody dryness.
its bright and cloudy orange with fizzy white head.
flavor is again limes, with bananas, *no* vinegar, and a nice sharpness.
its super dry and has a very long dry, sweet-sour finish.

Thanks to GodofThunder.  Pours a cloudy apricot color with white head and minimal lace.  Very good really funky nose.  Some armpit, foot, and basement.  This is balanced well with a bright spice and fruitiness, which makes this beer very enticing.  The flavor is very sour upfront but leaves little aftertaste.  Very dry and effervescent.  Quite delicious.

thanks to godofthunder for sharing this!  Lovely aroma, tart, citrusy, some sweetness, Pours a pale orange with a thin white head.  Tart citrus peels, great sourness, not too sour, very smooth, somewhat floral with hints of oak in the finish.  Wonderful.

Bottle (2002 vintage, red label) from Beers of Europe. Amber pour with an off white head. Excellent carbonation. Lovely gueuze aromas of green apples, herbs, cheese, grapefruit, pineapple. Barnyard aromas aplenty. Crisp, palate caressing flavours of lemon peel, grapefruit, lime, chives. Superb sweet/sour balance. Smooth, herby/fruity mouthfeel. Sharp,f ruity finish. Cracking stuff!

Bottle (Vintage 2003) which has been hand written on the label. Pours bright golden with a lively white head that slowly diminished. Surprisingly well carbonated. Wow what a nose - plenty of wood and leathery notes straight up. Then theres citrus, grapefruit and peach. The flavour is everything you want in a quality gueuze - woody, citrusy, grapefruit, peach, honey, almonds. This has to be the most well rounded gueuze Ive had the pleasure to drink. Superbly balanced. Not to mention the amazing drinkablilty. Remarkable. I cant thank Alex enough for sharing a bottle from his cellar. Amazingly generous - cheers mate!

* Whooopshh! * This pretty much describes my sensation as I took the first sip of the 2004 vintage of 3 Founteinens Oude Geueze Vintage series. This is one funky lambic right here, deserving a well-placed onomatopoetikon. Its body, a delicious-looking deep hazy orange goes well with the champagne-like fountain (no pun intended) head. This is extremely complex and powerful in taste: blue cheese, wet autumn leaves, grapes and hay with a sting of grassy hops blended in there somewhere. Sour, with a lingering acidic aftertaste clinging like a film on my palate, beckoning for another sip. Wow. If I hadnt already been through a few lambics before this rating, the Oude Geuze Vintage wouldve put me completely on my ass. Sooo strange, and yet very refreshing and drinkable. So much flavor, such an intricate blend. I cant believe this is only 6 % ABV; the vinous, bubbly palate is much more reminiscent of an 11 % champagne or something similar. All in all, the Oude Geuze Vintage from The Year of Our Lord 2007 is very nice, but regardless of all the originality I dont think I wouldve been able to drink more than a bottle of this at any given time. Lambics are just a tad bit too strange to become an ordinary commuter passenger on my platform.

Bottle at home. Pours a hazy orange with a thin white head. Aroma of blue cheese, leather and more definite brett aromas. Flavor is very dry, mostly sour and slightly bitter with some lemon. Quite interesting brew.

Bottled. in a train in Belgium. Golden coloured. Unclear. Dense small off white head. Earth, barnyard, leather, intense sourness and soem spice and fruits in the aroma. UPDATED: FEB 16, 2010 2005 vintage from a 37cl bottle.  Pours darker than expected, apple cider amber, with a really nice, big, fizzly head. A little chalky around the edges, maybe the yeast got stirred up.  This is a really full bodied gueuze, lively, bursts with an intense fermented apple quality thats really neat and reminds me of Perseguidor 3.

Big coarseish offwhite head. Hazy orange body. Aroma of apple, metal, leather, and barnyard, surprisingly delicate. Dry-acidic leathery lemony barnyard taste with apple notes. Mid-bodied. 750 ml "champagne" bottle, now available in Norway (Vinmonopolet). ABV is 6%. Bottle date: 14-02-2007, the "best before" date also reads 02-2007, which obviously must be a misprint. [37.5cl 2005 bottle, home, 03/01/10] Poured with absolutely no head.  Aroma was incredibly funky: barnyard, lemon, leather, vinegar, earthy tones. Very sour, acidic, funky taste that lasts and lasts. 37.5 cl bottle, 07 03/ 2002.  Clear straw with rising bubbles and a perky white head.  Nose is honeydew, wildflowers, lemon and horse stall.  Quite a contrast.  Lightly sparkling with a mild tongue burn.  Taste is green apple, lemon peel, grapefruit juice, hay and finally leather.  An elusive sublime sweetness lures you back for another sip.

Ahh... a great geuze but more mild than for instance Cantillon and Hanssens. The traditional sour aroma and sparkling palate, but a tad more watery. flavor is dry, bertty, sour grape, citrus, definetly one of the best sour ales ive ever had, no off flavors, just good taste all around.

Bottled 09/04/2005. Honey orange pour with a fine looking white head and some nice visible carbonation. Aroma becomes more pronounced as the beer warms. Bottle. Dated 09/04/2005. Pours a hazy deep honey colour with a huge slighlty off white head. Aromas are quite tart with plenty of lemony acidity and barn yard funk. Bottle from Bierkoning, Amsterdam. Dated 12/04/2005. Murky orange body with almost no head. Aroma is very sour and tart. Taste of apples, wood and soured fruits. Watery mouthfeel, dries up at the end.
