Flavor is pool water, fizzy, some acidity, lightly sweet, oddly abrasive.   Fizzy frothy fluffy mouthful, sugary feeling.   Surely not the best bottle.

Nice stuff! Orangish/gold pour.  Fluffy head.  Aroma is nice and tart with sour apple, minerals, wet earth, sour stone fruits and wood. Flavor is sour and fruity.  Funky with wet earth, sour apples, sour apricots...mmmmmm.

Oude geuze 3f vintage 2005
Bottle @ brasserie420
Wonderful cork-pop, good carbonation!
Incredible complex nose, everything ranging from dust to honey, green apples, grapefruit. Really the copy of the scent of the 3F cellars.
The taste is just great. Honey, apple juice. Not acetic at all. Clean, crisp and mineral. So elegant!! The acidity is perfect, not overdone, just perfectly balanced with the hops. Great!
The Ferrari of Lambics.

Bottle from Bierkoning. Dated 12/04/2005. Murky orange body with almost no head. Really prickly and carbonated. Very sour and tart. Taste of apples, wood and soured fruits. Nice blend. (Still cant warm to the style though.)

Bottle, dated 2005/12/04 and consumed in September 2009.  The pour yields a progressively more hazy, brassy, golden-amber colored body.  A moderate head of foamy, off-white foam settles slowly to a think, lasting blanket, wet lacing mostly rejoining the body.  The aroma approaches perfection, enticingly tart and fruity with notes of peach, lemon, soured apricot, and big, funky, buggy wood.  Barnyard must, horseblanket, and hints of wild grasses impart earthy depth, enhancing the citric acidity beautifully on the nose. The flavor proves to be the perfect counterpart, initially shockingly tart, but settling in quickly to deliciously balanced and juicy.  Peach, apricot, nectarine, and lemon again rule the day, with spicy, musty, saturated oak lending its signature funk.  Bright and vibrant in the mouth, the palate is zesty and refreshing, acidic and puckering, yet even keeled and semi-dry.  This is simply a masterful creation.  Absolutely one of the best beers on planet Earth.I also had a bottle from 2003/07/03 at De Heeren van Liedekercke within a few days of the above rating.  Slightly less impressive, this vintage maintained the same general direction yet fell short in terms of intense focus of both flavor and mouthfeel.  Still astoundingly delicious, this older bottle only served to solidify my opinion of the 2005 vintage as being one of the finest beers I have ever had.

2002 Vintage. Pours copper golden, topped with a modest sized white head. Aroma of Dry, somewhat tart aroma, with lots of wood,  lactic acid, barnyard, and overripe fruit. Dry, very tart on the palate, and very woody, with lemon, green apple, and some herbal notes. Flavor is more tart than the aroma. Dry, citric finish. Nice Gueuze.

2003...mildly hazy amber golden pour with nice white head. Aroma is somewhat sweet with rotten fruit. Some nice lemony woody tones are coming through. Nice tartness, quite dry, woody tannins. Quite delicious.
Pours nice orange/golden with a small head. Hints of oak with an appealing sourness in the smell. Tastes of sour apples. Good and dry finish that tingles the back of your throat.

UPDATED: OCT 6, 2010 Bottle 2005 at Plan B, 2004 at Ølbaren and 2005 at plovmand, thanks pal! :-)
Orange golden colour with a huge long yellowish head. 
The aroma is smooth, dry and dusty with notes of grape, oak, apples and poppy seeds. 
The taste is very similar to the aroma with strong notes of dry grape and a hint of grass.
The 2004 seems to be a bit more smooth and balanced than the 2005.

2002 bottle labeled Vintage. This clear golden Lambic poured with a generous white head and a sour fruit aroma. This one has aged very nicely. The sharpness has mellowed to a mild sourness that leaves a pleasant tingle on the palate.

UPDATED: MAR 3, 2010 375ml.  again thanks to brad (forgot to note the vintage).... pours a hazier apricot brown with a lively effervescemt white head... aroma not as funky as the de cam but more citrus fruit focused. vibrant citrus with funk and lemon.  less assertive as well but still quite a nice lambic essence....lively, somewhat funky with subdued earthiness and grass with an added lemony-citrus component.

Lovely gueuze with allot of barnyard funk to it, complex woody, bretty and lemony with a complex dirty, sour and dry finish. Colour is also lovely, complex deep, hazy orange. Causes some serious throat cleansing to say the least.

Bottle 04-12-2005. A hazy orange/golden colored beer, with a off white head. The aroma of dough/bread with wood. Some sourness and fruits. The taste is dry bitter, wood, sour with fruits like citrus. Refreshing on a sunny day. The aftertaste is dry and bitter for a long time.
Tasted at the San Diego International Beer Festival.  Hazy golden with a fizzy white head.  Vinegar aroma and a crisp sour taste.

37,5 cl, bottled in 2005. As the website home.scarlet.be/pajottenland wrote, I conserved the bottle lying and I tried to pour it out like it should be. However I forgot to empty the first few centiliters and  to let the beer run over a bit, I held the bottle and the glass diagonal (to avoid the yeast coming into the glass), turned around the glass first so the Gueuze was touching the whole glass and indeed: I had a fantastic white head. Even when the glass was empty for 3/4 I still had a medium lacing white head. There were some bubbles however in this hazy golden-orange beer.  I poured it out in a 33 cl Jupiler-glass, because this one was resembling the best a Gueuze-glass. Thanks to the previously announced website for giving me those hints! The beer itself then: the smell was attacking my nose with a rather sharp sour taste, with also some tastes of fruit making it milder. The taste was also fantastic: first of all you have the sour taste of a Gueuze, but it is not too sour, because it is very well balanced with a fruity aftertaste. There are also some notes of wheat. This is also a very refreshing beer, certainly because I drunk it when it was hot. It was a pity the glass was empty, because I enjoyed the beer so much. Oh, and with the little gueuze left in the bottle: throw it away, because all the yeast is in that last 2 cl destroying all the good taste (luckily I only tasted those last 2 cls when my glass was already empty). Top beer, top quality!

Bottle that was picked up at Dranken Geers, Oostakker, Belgium 09-06-09 consumed, West Runton, campsite North Norfolk 14-06-09   Pours orange amber with medium white head.Rustic aroma, touch of pepper, sour lemon and other funky fruitiness some apple maybe, though aroma could have been a little better and was perhaps the one weak point? Taste is wonderfully tart but not too sharp, sourness is there, lemon rind, lovely soft fruity tang, dry tartiness. Excellent stuff.  A6 A5 F9 P5 Ov16  4.1
4 years old bottle, citrus, golden oranje colour, aminimal head, heavily sour start but light sour end with sweet and bitter, medium body, sticky, long finish, not my cup of tea, but goodish
user_location: Cambridge and Kladno(Czech Rep.), Cambridgeshire, ENGLAND

Hazy golden beer with a thin white head, amazing sour wooden grapefruity aroma and taste, the sourness hits your tastebuds. makes a homerun and stays to celebrate in your mouth for quite a bit. Amazing.

From a 375mL Bottle, Vintage 2005.  Mostly transparent, honey gold colored body with a two finger head of fizzy white.  Fruity, funky aromas of pear and apricot supplemented by a restrained tartness composed mainly of lactic and citric acid.  Softer, citrus notes of orange blossoms and floral peach, sharpened by some tart, tannic white grape skins.  Beautiful bouquet.  Light bodied, heavily carbonated mouthfeel with a dry, prickling carbonation and mild acidity.  Not nearly as acidic as many gueuzes, but abounds with brett-induced funk and a plethora of fruity ester nuances, especially apricot and peach.  Moderate tartness with some grape skin tannins, but the funky fruity notes that emerge on the palate are what make this truly remarkable.  There are better gueuzes out there in terms of the complexity of the acid profile, but the aroma on this one is wonderful.  Thanks for sharing, Julian!
Bottle says 2005, consumed some time in 2009.  Pours a golden copper body with a white head.  Honey, funk and leather, some light brett and very low acidity.  Very session able Gueuze i thought.

UPDATED: JAN 28, 2012 Sample at CPH beerfestival. 2005 edition. Medium head with medium duration. Color is amber. Aroma and taste are lactose acid, fruits, malt and hops. Rerated @ fonefan tasting. New rating 8/3/9/4/17. Old rating 7/3/7/4/15

As a relative newcomer to geueze and conscious it was perhaps an acquired taste, this was the first one that really made me see the light. Where others had been a little overly dry or funky for my uninitiated palate this seemed amazingly balanced and genuinely delicious. There were no overly dominating flavours and Id highly recommend this and the standard oude gueuze (contradiction in terms perhaps) for anyone new to geueze beers. After drinking it my appreciatation of all the others Ive since tried has improved. A superb drink!

bottle 37.5cl,vintage 2005, lively beer: the cork popped out of the bottle after removing the sheath above it, very nice stable white head, golden colour. Smell: wood. Taste: a very good balance between acid and bitter. Very complex and tongue-rotating beer. Also very nice grapefruit, sweet in the aftertaste.

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2009 A cute hazy orange geuze with rosy hues when the light hits it right.  Sour orange aromas lifted by a good pink grapefruit bitterness.  Amazing bitter orange in the mouth with sweet, light rose petal notes. A big bubbly tongue that shies away from the itchy, prickly feeling I despise. This is to-die-for. Sweet, crisp and sour but not to the massively salivation inducing extent. 

Re-rate on the 6-9-2003:thanks to mesandsim deep  mustardy  full of sweet and sour loveliness. Full of deep lemony wood and fuzzy sherbert. Banging.

375 ml. bottle shared by mreusch.  Date on bottle is 15/04/2003. Pour is hazed golden orange with with a noisy bubbly 2 inch head. Aroma of burnt rubber, and funky sour lactic cheesiness. Very sharp tartness.  There is wood present as well.  Doesnt sound real good, but it was very assertive and soft at the same time - nice nose.   Taste is the acidic sour mineral cheesiness of the nose.  Big funk, big tart, big sour.  The intensity fades a bit as it opens up, and like the nose, softens up nicely.  This beer tastes very alive.  Palate is dry - funky, sour and lasting.  This was a lot of fun to try, thanks a million Matt.

UPDATED: MAR 26, 2009 375ml bottle, 15/04/2003 vintage, with another thanks to ygtbsm94!  Pours a hazy golden with a minimal white head.  Aroma is Funky with a capital F, with some sour grapes, must, light citrus and aged wood.  Flavor is more of the same, with more funk, must, sour and tart.  Very similar to the regular, but the age definitely adds a little notch.  Sharper in some places, more cohesive in others.  Nice stuff, thanks again Brad!
(37,5 cl bottle) Aroma and taste of sour wood and citrus with a bit of a funky taste as well. Long finish. Very refreshing!

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2011 Bottle shared by Shyam.  Very outstanding character.  Aroma is of sour wood, white pepper, gelatin, multiple citrus examples, mold, sour funk and earth.  Flavors of all the same - like biting into a molding fruit.  Finish is long, dry and tart.  Better than JJ, IMO.  And for sure better than Girardin Black Label.

Bottle, 2004. The aroma is sour, strong yeast and fruity, very nice. The head is medium large, white and creamy-foamy with a long duration. The body is cloudy and orange. The taste is very sour and refreshing with a medium duration. The beer is very dry in the mouth and has a astringent finish with a normal duration. The body is light to medium.

Bottle shared with Alex of Brasserie 4:20, thanks again Alex for sharing a special bottle with me.  Pours hazy yellow with a thin head.  Great farmhouse aroma with some sour citris notes as well.  Sour funk all over the place with a complex finish that lasted for a solid minute.  I am usually not crazy about sours, but this was unique and better than other gueuze I have had.

Bottle shared by Sam the Turd (thanks, Mr. Ferguson!).  A tasty treat, to be sure.  Hazy orange/gold pour with surprisingly huge bubbly white head.  Tart wood, lemon, cherry, peach, dust, hay, barnyard, love, joy, transcendence.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye.  Vintage version dated 13/04/2002.  The look is cloudy, peached colored, with a light white head. Very inviting.  The smell is very woody, oak, fruits, tart, old smelling, funk, and barnyard.  Very nice.  The taste is acidic, fruits, wood.  Good carbonation level.  Nice dry finish.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye. "vintage version" dated 13/04/2002. Orange in color and lightly hazy with a good sized white head. Aroma is tart, fruity and spicy with wood and the signiture gueuze funk. Taste is tart with citrus, apple, wood, spiciness, and funky earth.

(750ml bottle, Vintage version dated 13/04/2002)  Pours a clear yellow body with a tall white head.  Aroma of wood, mustiness, barnyard, horse blanket, light grapefruit, cork, and apple.  Flavor of citrus (light acidity), earthiness, and brett with a carbonated mouthfeel and dry wood finish.

Bottle thanks to bu11zeye (yes, this is the vintage, bottled 13/04/02, with "vintage" clearly labeled on the bottle). Pours with a huge, foamy, off-white head that lasts over a hazy orange body. Aroma of funk, apple, caramel, fruity esters, wood, must, library books, earthiness, and some honey dew and honey suckle when it warms. Taste is sour, woodsie, woddy, with must, light strawberry, light citrus. Very clean overall, but not as adventurous as the regular oude gueze. Not particularly puckering. Fizzy carbonation.
37,5 cl bottle. 12APR05 bottled. Nice pop at opening. Looks like gold. Not convinced that its better than the standard 3 fonteinen gueuze.

Bottle shared by Turdferguson - thanks, Sam! Vintage 2003. Gorgeous bright orange pour, classic gueuze appearance, with a bit of cloudy yeast and a nice lasting head to it. The flavor is really vibrant, with an intense acidity to it that isnt aggressive so much as it is deep and suffusing. Lovely.

Vintage 2005.  Bottle thanks to Davinci.  Clear amber golden with creamy white head.  Aroma is a nice dirty funk, orange and other citrus as well.  Flavor is big tart funk with a good amount of dirtiness, lemon, orange, obvious grapefruit, medium acidity, really dry, Lively carbonation on medium, tart body.  Very tasty and with out many vinegar notes, very nice.
wow....great funky nose with a ton of complex and tart flavors....2003 vintage brought by wetherel...thanks so much!!!!

2003 at AlohaCs.  Thanks for this.  Super sour nose.  Aroma was almost perfect.  I found myself just breathing in the scent of it and salivating.  Very sour/tart.  Jumps around in the mouth.  Amazing.  Yum

2003 vintage 375mL bottle from ygtbsm94.  Thanks Brad! Definitely the vintage version, which I have searched long to try.  Opened at alohaCs 2008 end of the year tasting. Wow.  Very sour.  Most people at the party enjoyed this a lot.  Lots of carbonation, which combined with the sourness makes the tongue tingle.  Very nice peachy tartness.

2003 Vintage bottle Wetherel brought to the holiday tasting we helped throw.  Pours orange/yellow with a bright 1 finger tan head.   Nose is supremly tart.  Taste is acidic and beautifally tart.  wowza wowza.

Vintage 2004, Light amber coloured geuze with some average carbonation and a medium white head. Light sour grainy touched aroma, refreshing. Full palate. Finish is sour fruity balanced with some herby hints. Nice.

UPDATED: SEP 15, 2010 Bottle dated 09 04 2004.  Cloudy strw colored with medium white head that fades quickly.  Aroma of citrus and dust.  Full bodied.  Taste of sour grapefruit and must.  Beautiful.
Vintage 2007, courtesy of Armand and his wife - thank you!  Shared with Bastien, Arne & Cameron on the day we crated the Schaerbeekse.  Highly complex, lots of character, very tasty.

Clear goldblond coloured beer with medium carbonation and small white head. Sour aroma. Full sprankling palate. Finish is sour diminishing, a litte bitter. Noticed some strange aftertaste for a geuze.
cloudy gold orange coloured body with a white head a hoppy sourig fruity aroma a sourig fruity hoppy taste with a sourig bitter finish

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2013 Bottled, 2003 version. Cloudy orange coloured. Very nice complex nose, fruity, dusty, pleasantly tart. Flavour is quite easy going for a oude geuze, sour but not extreme. Very nice geuze.

Bottle, bought @ Ølbutikken, Cph. [vintage 2002] #2 Birthday beer. Pours clear golden with a medium, frothy, white head. Fine duration lots of bubbles - impressive for a gueuze. Aroma is very nice, some cellar, lots of green apples, funkiness, lactic and citric acids. Still maintains a softness and elegance with just a tad of vanilla and oak. Highish carbonation, super dry mouthfeel. Just a tad on the watery side. Flavour is tart, but not overwhelmingly so, apples, citric and lightly lactic. Very soft and nice, but not near the best gueuzes IMHO.

Vintage 2003.  Pours hazy dark yellow with a small, fizzy, white head, somewhat lasting with fair lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (bread, hay, straw, meal), light hops (flowers, grass), average yeast (horse blanket, earth) with notes of grapes and cask.  Light bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and a sour finish.  Long duration, light sweetness, moderate acidity and sourness.

2003 vintage shared by Jason.  Well my notes on this one aren’t very good as they went through the washing machine, but those numbers were correct because that survived.  I recall it was straw colored and very hazy with a nice white head.  The aroma and flavors were extremely well balanced but not overly sour.  This beer would be a great one to introduce people to Gueuzes because it’s so perfectly balanced.  Nice leathery sour fruits but not overly so.

2003 Vintage.  Poured effervescent healthy golden with a medium cap of fizzy white head and lots of rising carbonation.  The aroma was large and in charge with apple cider vinegar, leather, and dusty funk throughout.. warmth brought out a pinch of lemon zest and some floral character.. awesome!  Prickly vinegar and lemons on the tip of the tongue with citrus meat and dry oaky notes following.. vinegar and Bretty funkage were laced throughout, and this maintained tremendous balance the whole way.. finished long and sour with apple skins and funk.  Again, perfect balance on the palate.. soft enough that you can drink this all day and not tear up your stomach.. great, great stuff!

Found a bottle at a shop in belgium on a recent trip.
An off brownish orange color with a small soapy white head that dissipates somewhat quickly.  Aroma has some tart citrus qualities I know this will be sour, a good amount of dry oak.  Palate is puckering and coated.  Flavor is very tart lots of sour fruits I thought a hint of berry and some apple skins over a dry wood taste that pulls the moisture off my tounge.  A nice beer.

[1250-20080404] 375mL bottle. Sour flattened cardboard malt aroma tucked in a bed of old pine needles. Hazy, light brown orange body with a long-lasting creamy white head. Mostly sour flavour with mild grains, mild malt and mild citrus. Medium body is super bitter. A puckerer! Yum.
(2004 Vintage; w/ jerc, tupalev)
UPDATED: JUL 19, 2009 38cl, exclusive brew, from De Hopduvel Gent,  very complex, balanced, hazy, rocky head, very good sour Geuze, a topper!

37,5 cl bottle at Den Tatoverede Enke, København. Cloudy amber orange color, fine white head. Aroma is acidic with oak and wood - just fantastic. Flavor is acidic with green apples. Wonderful long lasting aftertaste. A great gueuze!

(2004 vintage at Pikkulintu on 2008-07-12) Pale orange. Hazy. Largish pale white head that disappeared quickly. Sour nose with wood and bit of cowhouse. Medium and dry palate with little carbonation. Bit fruity flavour, sour, wood, some bitterness and bit of sweetness in taste. Very good geuze.

2004 chiara buona schiuma persistente note acide di cantina legno legggera ossidazione ma delicata in bocca acidità media non agressiva note aspre leggermente astringenti tocco di buccia di agrume amara leggero legno ossidazione molto piacevole non agressiva negli aromi

37,5cl 2004 bottle. Hazy golden/brown, lacing foamy head. Sour and malty nose,  some funk, apple seeds. Quite smooth, but not that special. Flavor is something else alright, strong apple seedy sourness, apple wine and earth. Natural dry apple finish. Medium bodied and smooth palate. Just keeps getting better with every sip.

UPDATED: MAR 25, 2009 Bottle from bu11zeye, thanks.  Dated 13/04/2002, 6 years old. Pours with a big foamy head, the bottle was a light gusher. The color is dark murky/dirty golden, cannot see through the beer. Aroma is signature 3 Fonteinen rubber heavy. Then there is thick aged gueze maltiness to it and even a light malt sweetness, again from the age. Flavor is light citrus and barnyard. Its lightly drying with lots of tartness at the end. Again, age shows with a heft in the none sour parts of the beer. Low acidity and pretty tame for a lambic. Very nice aged experience and definitely a defined difference from a fresh bottle. 750mL bottle, De Neve tumbler.Thanks to mreusch, 15/03/2003 in a generic tulip glass.  At first a very large head, bubbly.  Clear dark golden color.  I guess I wont get too much detailed here anymore its 3F, all rubber, dry dry rubber, their house character. rating stays.
user_location: HdG (past: NYC, KS, Rain City), Maryland, USA

text: UPDATED: MAY 27, 2008 A cloudy geuze. Light brown colour like in the photo. Lots of sourness. Mild nose some hints of honey. Grapefruit in the taste. A 0.375 l bottle of 2004 vintage.

Bottle from JoeinUccle. Thanks Joe!  2003 vintage.  Deep golden orange with a solid ring of white lace.  Nose is leather, horseblanket, oak, must. I love the smell of lambic, I must admit. The flavor is acidic, tart, dry, and funky.  Slightly sharp and acidic mouthfeel. Will have to put my other bottle up against the regular gueuze and see how it compares.  I really enjoyed this as I do with everything Drie Fonteinen makes.

(Bottled, 2004 vintage) Hazy golden with a medium, bubbly head.  very tart and dry aroma with wheaty maltiness. Tart and dry, honey-wheaty-malty, somewhat acidic flavor with some cellary notes. Medium-bodied with high carbonation. A pleasantly dry and tart geuze - maybe slightly too acidic, but that is just unnecessary whining.

375ml bottle (Pikkulintu, Helsinki, Bitter and Sour 2008)
Looked just like the picture - hazy orange, surprisingly lively head. Massive estery sharp aroma. Honey and flowery, but never sweet, as such. Massively sharp palate. Great grapefruity sourness. Long finish, more of the delicious same.

Thanks a ton to Turdferguson for sharing this 2003 vintage. Pours a very bright hazy orange gold with a 2 finger frothy white head. The nose is funky, grassy, sharp, vinous, some tartness, citrusy, fruity. The flavor is funky, nice tart acidic feel, grassy, fruity, sharp and spicy, a bit dry towards the end. Has a tart mouthfeel and finishes dry tart and warm. Very nice gueuze.

2002 vintage bottle drank in 2008: Poured a slightly hazy orangey color lambic with a medium white bubbly head with good retention and some lacing. Aroma of green apple with some acid and sour notes and some mild barnyard notes. Taste is less acidic then the aroma was suggesting with some sour notes and a barnyard feel which is quite interesting. There was some distinctive green apple notes which are similar to the Girardin gueuze. Full body with some good carbonation but slightly lower then I was expecting. I cant say that I see a huge difference form the regular geueze but IO as impressed nonetheless.

375 Bottle from Degarth, 07/03/2002. I had this a couple weeks ago, a small sample (also 2002, though a different month), and I wasnt crazy about it. At first this one wasnt too much better, although as it has warmed and breathed it has really opened up. Dry hay, funky aroma, earthy, black pepper. Flavor is earthy, tart, yeastiness, dry grass. A very dull kind of feel to this, as opposed to the brightness of many gueuzes. A tasty treat, though I prefer the normal oude gueuze.

37.5 cL bottle, thanks to Jeppe. Pours hazy orange with a slowly diminishing off-white head. Aroma is barnyard and orange fruity. Light wood note. Flavour starts solid citric before a dry wooden note appears. Light orange fruity finish with a that classic brett/yeasty tartness. Dry and wooden yet smooth and fruity too - nice balance.

Thanks to JoeMcPhee for sharing - 2002 vintage) - hazy, glowing orange beer - smells of fruit, cork, blue cheese, musty/earthy notes - bracing tartness up front - some phenolics and light cheesy character - a lot of cork and woody flavor - I can almost taste the cellar this was aged in - long, tongue-curling dryness - I enjoyed the strong earthiness of this one.

Bottle 16/04/2002.  Deep hazy orange-golden beer with a thick creamy white head.  Aroma is very rich and lovely.  Soft funky character and a fairly prominent musty/corky aroma.  Some strong funkiness and a nice soft fruitiness as well.  Flavour is quite earthy and musty.  There is a great sweet vanilla and mint aroma that comes up as the beer starts to warm as well.  Not terribly sour, but has a great earthy funkiness.  I definitely prefer the regular Oude Geuze though.

Bottle (2002). Large, rocky, white, diminishing head with fair lacing. A sparkling, lightly cloudy, light yellow body. Heavy yeast aroma of earth and musty. Aroma of apple and cask wood. Medium body, thin texture, lively carbonation and a bitter finish - to bitter if you ask me. The flavor is moderate sweet, heavy acidic and moderate bitter. Not my favourite gueze because of the bitter finish - and not acidic finish. But the beer is still well balanced and good

2008-04-04. Bright hazy orange body with a big white head that fades. (3+) Aroma is quite musty, modest sweet and sour lemon citrus notes. (7+). Flavour is quite sour, with the sourness seeming to increase in proportion to the size and frequency of your sips. Astringent lemons and citrus seeds. Average palate is just a touch thin but suits it, effervescent. Zippy and complex but pleasantly drinkable in modest quantities. Bottle labeled 2004 Vintage from Bier Tempel, Brugge

Vintage version, 2004, bottle shared with and courtesy of Jerc and Mabel from their recent Belgium trip.  Nice dark, hazy, fiery yellow, small white head.  Aroma is really sour and really funky - almost spicy.  Intense sourness in taste, very acidic.  Just  tad thin in the body - makes it a little too acidic.  Otherwise complex mouth puckering loveliness.

75cL bottle, bottled on 2/2/07.  Im a 3 Fonteinen whore, the only thing "bad" I can say about this particular bottle is that the aroma was just a little off.  Aside from that, this expensive ass bottle is ~almost~ reason enough to move to Beersel and become a bum hoping to lick the empty barrels as they are cleaning them.

UPDATED: FEB 16, 2012 Re-rate 2/8/12: Bottle shared at the 2nd Israeli Sour Tasting. 2007 vintage. Hazy orange color with a white head. Amazing aroma full of citrus fruits, some leather and barnyard. Sour lemony flavor with an astringent finish. Medium-bodied. Wonderful and really quaffable. 9/4/8/4/18=4.3

(3/11/08) Bottle at Le Poechenellekelder in Brussels. 2004 vintage. Hazy orange with medium white head. Aroma of barnyard and a lot of citrus. Dry flavor full of citric-like sourness and nice bretty funk. Medium-bodied with lively carbonation. Excellent. 8/4/8/4/16=4

375ml bottle 07/03/2003 thanks to ygtbsm for trading me this gem.  Pours a clear copper with an off white head.  Nose is phenomenal.  Lots of barnyard, hay, wood, and acidity that mellow out in a few short minutes.  The sugar and apples make themselves known to sweeten up the bouquet.  The flavor is all around tart and dry.  The first flavor I pick up on is tart cherries, that are picked a couple months too soon.  When they are a light red and still hard.  Very little acidity at five years old.  Oak, lemons, floral notes, and earth come through with a bitter fruit pit that is surrounded by a slight sourness.  Finishes dry with that earthy pit bitterness.  An interesting geuze for sure.

Bottled in April 2004. Clear pale amber with a white lively head. Nose is dominated by barnyardy aromas, a bit acetic and a strong wood feature. Very mellow and rounded in mouth, with a dry and slightly bitter end.

UPDATED: AUG 30, 2009 Bottle 37,5 cl, 2003 vintage. Pours a cloudy yellow with a big white head while puring, but it fades very fast. The aroma is like any of the 3 fonteinen-gueuzes, you know all those things which are usually smelled on a farm. The taste is fresh, sour and gets also a bit sweet in the end, when it also gets a more bitter "bite". A great 3 fonteinen gueuze, but the 98 anniversary is far superior

Bottle. Vintage 2002. Pours a hazy orange color with a fast disappearing white head. Has a fruity tart sour branyard aroma with some woody yeasty hints. Fruity tart sour flavor with some woody citrus hints. Fruity tart sour finish with some sweetish hints, with a long sour aftertaste. Yummy!!

Bottle. (Vintage 15/02/2003).  Took off cage and 15 seconds later the cork pops out on its own.  Sweet orange peel, apple juice, musty yeast aroma.  Hazy orange-amber with giant head.  Orange-apple juice flavor up front followed by a sour, musty, barnyard.  Nice sweet-sour flavor - sourness much more subdued than many gueuzes.

37,5cl bottle: Vintage 2002 bought @ olbutikken, Copenhagen! Pours hazy orange with a decent white head. Authentic 3 fonteinen aroma - sour, oak, wood, vinegar & fruity lemon. Well rounded & dry! Super!

Tasted 2008-03-08. 2004 version. Pours hazy yellow with white head. Aroma: Funky, sour barnyardish scent. Apples, citrus. Flavour: Acidic and slightly bitter. Less aggressive than the regular 3F geuze. Very round and yet powerfull. Tart and quite dry. Love it!

Bottle stamped 09/04/2004. 37,5 cl. A fantastic geuze from 3 fontainen. Sweet/sour fruity notes of citrus. Has a dry and rounded aftertaste that last a long time.
The colour is typical shady guezish.

Bottled @ 2004, bottle, 75 cl. Taste yesterday with William ...
Hazy golden to orange color, and little creamy white head.
Aroma oak, floral, sour, fruits.
Medium body.
Taste sourness, woody, great malts character. Almost perfect in every imaginable way. Soft bitterness. Dry finish.

The usual Drie Fonteinen geuze citrus class topped by a wonderful smooth and silky character. This is as classy as it gets. In the end, its of course not so different from their other gueuzes, so I can only adore it, but having had 2002, 2003 and 2004, they all felt a bit aged already, perhaps simply a side-effect of the smoothness of the blend. Still, I think I prefer the fresher, forward hay character of the regular gueuze. At this level of quality though, take my comments lightly, because its really a reflection of personal tastes and theres not a trace of objectivity involved.

UPDATED: FEB 5, 2012 Bottle 750ml.Unclear - hazy orange color with a small, virtually none appearance, virtually none lacing head. Aroma is sour, apple, lemon - grape, wood, horse blanket. Flavor is moderate sour with a average to long duration, and a dry dry finish. Body is medium, texture is watery, carbonation is flat. Very nice (020208)  8-4-8-4-17 
Bottle 750ml. [ Vintage 2007 ]. Clear medium yellow orange colour with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, off-white head. Aroma is moderate to light heavy barnyard, citrus, fruity, light wood. Flavour is moderate to heavy sweet and light to moderate acidic with a long duration, citrus, dry, wood, fruity. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft - flat. [20120127]  8-4-9-4-18
Quite funky on the nose after a apple juice looking pour with big foamy head.  Apple, citrus, acidy lemon zestiness all come across in the flavor and mouthfeel.  Quite solid.

[2003] Poured a hazy golden color with a medium sized, white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of horsey funk, apple, wood, and feet.  Taste of lemony sour, apple, dry wood, with a pleasant sour finish.  Soft mouthfeel.

37.5cl bottle shared courtesy of egajdzis. 2003 vintage (bottle stamped 07/06/2003). Poured a deep and lightly hazy golden color with an averaged sized head. Aromas of yeast, citrus, musty cellar, green apple fruitiness, and funky. Tastes follow suit. Lightly tart finish. Nice.

Thanks to egajdzis for sharing this.  Vintage 2003.  Pours a hazy golden with hints of orange and a medium bubbly head.  Aroma of mixed citrus, floral notes, musty basement, horse blanket and a general funkiness. Flavor was tart and musty, wheat, funky, sour and nice.

2003 Vintage: ultra serious style but perhaps I should not be surprised. Very active fizzy head eaely but this soon settles to leave a snow white, creamy residue. Chunky lacing too. Hazy glowing apricot in colour. Nose is a touch subdued; salt, vinegar, sour and ctirus fruits, but Im probably not doing the right thing by assessing this beer straight out of the fridge. Palate structure is very classy and Im sure this beer will look ok as a 7yr old. Lots of balance early with sour grapey notes, perhaps on the elegant side of things, but the intensity slowly ramps up through the palate and the beer becomes progressively more tangy, sour and almost spicy and bitter. Plenty of fizz as well. Yup - the ducks nuts.

2002 vintage. Hazy orange color with a frothy lasting head. Sensational aroma of citrus, cellar, yeast and bitterness. Extremely dry in flavor with a great aftertaste, heavy carbonation despite the age. A gueuze I wont forget!

My 1000th beer! 375ml of the 2004 vintage. Hazy deep amber colour with moderate carbonation and a big, but short-lived off-white head. Strong aroma of yeast, the barnyard, bitter orange and sherry. The flavour had a citrus edge, with more yeast and orange peel. The finish had plenty of acidity, yet a touch of smoothness, and left a long aftertaste. Excellent.

750ml bottle, caged, corked and foil wrapped purchased from the brewery. Bottled 16 Apr 2002. Poured a cloudy orange with a small light beige head. Rich aroma of bubblegum, peaches, horseblanket, and grapefruit. The flavor is more or less dominated by sourness with some hop notes sticking out from the grapefruitiness. Mild sour bitter finish. This is damn fine stuff.
2002. Almost clear orange of colorwith a large foamy head. A dry aroma of oak, horseback and lovely sour notes. A flavor of horseback, oak, cider and dry!

UPDATED: JAN 2, 2008 2004 consumed in 07. Hazy orange liquid rolls from the bottle, awesome lively carbonation generating and sustaining a thick and creamy white head that is reluctant to recede, eventually mostly diminishing and remaining creamy. Incredible liveliness for vintage lambic - no doubt this wouldve endured multiple decades of careful storage with grace and little degradation. Barnyard funk is focused and penetrates multilayered acidic citrus attacks, a barrage that, at its core, is floral and heartwarming. Must is off-centered and releases cobweb and doctors the overall profile to create a very formidable powerhouse that doesnt overexcel in any one area, but feels boisterous and vigorous from afar and until the glass is drawn from the nose at long last. Lemon, followed by orange and soft sour pomegranate, play the leading roles in the citrus character affront. Pineapple juice-soaked Ridgeway Blue cheese seems to be a crust at the outlying borders of each inhalation. Nearly perfect in every imaginable way. The flavor accelerates acidic tendencies and stifles mustiness initially. Bitterness is soft and soothing, sweetness is medium but recedes quickly. Sourness is moderate and refreshing, never overpowering. The finish is subtly drying, ever-so-slowly beckoning another contemplative sip(or gulp, its too tempting). The mouthfeel is soft and light-medium bodied, with silken carbonation and a completing velvety blanket and malt. A staple this would be, were it available to me. Oh, pity.

Vintage 2004.  Pours a light copper, perhaps a roasted orage color.  Aroma is a punch in the face.  With a dank earthiness up front, bowing out to an acidic component, perhaps bright lemons and an acetic quality.  There is a finishing note of strewn hay and meadow flowers.  Awesome.  The flavor is equally as complex.  The acidity is there, but is so elegant and graceful, I am awed.

Totally different beer type, the Gueuze, and this seems to be the benchmark.  Deep strong moldy nose that betrays the hazy copper tone.  Taste is utterly sublime, where the aroma is nothing but subtle, the tastes are, ranging from metal to bitterness to lush fruit.  Fantastic.

UPDATED: JUN 6, 2010 2004 Vintage, shared by kmweaver. Cloudy pale body with a small white head. Super funky, blue cheese nose is lightly sweet, moderately acidic with pineapple, lemon and horseblanket. The flavor is lightly sweet, moderately sour with lemon/lime, melon rind, light oxidation and yogurt. Medium body is soft with gentle carbonation. Red label 2002. Big citrus nose, lots of grapefruit peal, lots of lemon, cobwebs, hay and cheese. The taste is moderately sour, lightly sweet, some cotton candy, lemon, grapefruit rind, and honey. Very similar to the magical 99 vintage.  10/5/9/4/18 = 4.6

375 ml 2004 bottle thanks to boboski.  Beautiful head on this golden orange pour.  Aromas of tart fruit and lemon.  Flavors were very acidic.  NIce tart flavors and gueuzey.  Can I say gueuzey?  Well thats what it was.  Very Very yummy

2003 vintage, poured from a 375 ml.  Hazy, golden appearance.  Aroma of springtime mist, all wet leaves, young flowers and distant funk.  Goat cheese, feta, and blue cheese with bold pungency; watermelon, berries, and pepper in the lighter moments, though again dominated by the must, mold, and wet cat.  The sour burst of taste is all lemon juice at first, though a lovely, light sweetness of almond runs through it, giving way to vinegar, wet juniper and ginger dressing.  Rather tepid, but still exciting and bracing in its presentation.  Pears, apples, sweetened lemon even it out.  Light, and brilliantly dry in the mouth, finishing with a lot of tang and perfect animalistic funk.  Perhaps even a bit more bizarre than expected, especially for a comparitively young example.  To my memory this pales in comparison to the older vintages, though quite beautiful and intriguing in its own right.  Thanks for sharing, Ken!

2002.  Fine spritzy head, drops at a moderate pace, leaving a rich golden beer striking as the colour is far more golden than I expected.   Soft yet rich nose, with what might be called that distinctive 3fonteinen nose. The flavour is far more rounded than the normal gueuze, yet maintains a long dry finish.  
All in all a really nice treat.
Bottle. Pours a nice hazy orange colour. Sour yeasty citrus aroma. Soft sour and sweet flavour with fuits yeast and a bit of mold. Sour fruitish finish.
Bottle from Noel Cuveliers.  Orange gold with thin off whtie head.  A rather nutty grapey geuze.  Bit of lemonade.  Nice.
Bottle labeled 07/03/2003. Poured a dark gold color with a white head. Slightly sharp horse blanket aromas. Upfront sourness. Light-to-medium body well-carbonated, dry/tart finish.

April 16, 2002 Vintage Bottle, Sampled October 2007
Pours with a lightly hazy, cherry tinged, light amber color (quite dark for a Gueuze / Lambic) and is crowned by an initially two-finger thick, light tan colored head that is a mix of large and tightly beaded froth that leaves some lacing patterns on the sides of the glass as it recedes.  Ah yes, the aroma is just want I need; funky, woody,  tart and fruity, it smells oh so good.  Aromatic notes of cured leather, ripe plastic (in the process of curing), urea, dried mushrooms and a touch of farmhouse cheese are all noticeable.  The aromatic tart notes run the gamut from hints of lactic, acetic, definitely citric, with notes of tart apples, sour grapes and even some touches of tart, exotic fruit.  Other aromas of rotting wood, cedar, spicy oak, damp cellars made of stone and thick-amply-aged wood structure add more complexity to the aroma.

Soft and almost creamy up front before the acidity kicks in.  The acidity is never hard or overbearing though (which I sometimes like and even crave in a Lambic) and in fact melds quite well with a substantial (for a Lambic) texture & body.  The acid is most notably lactic in character, but has touches of citric flavors at times.  Notes of crab-apple, un-ripe star-fruit, touches of grapefruit (and even more than that at times) and a green, un-ripened, sauvignon blanc grape flavor add to the fruit component of this beer.  Despite the supple texture and heft of this beer it seems quite bone dry.  The carbonation, though light for a Gueuze, adds a zesty textured touch of froth to each sip.  The flavor is not quite as funky as the aroma was, but this is still quite funk driven.  Flavors of woody mushrooms, damp leather in the finish, cherry pits, most definitely musty and even a bit moldy at times.  Touches of ephemeral vanilla, butter cream flavors (or is that just evoked from the texture), uriatic acid (cat pee to the layman) and wild flower petals add to the subtle backdrop of this beer.  Quite tannic at times, almost coating the mouth, though not the teeth like a very tannic green tea, in light astringency.

I could wish for a bit more carbonation here as I like my Gueuzes to be very effervescent, but this is a damn fine example of the art.  Very well blended, very well integrated, there is nothing that is dominant here.  I do love a good Lambic, Gueuze especially, and I wish that I had the ability to drink more of these on a regular basis.  Almost a bit too refined for my tastes; still rustic though and definitely a finely crafted product, but I think I prefer the regular non-vintage, and the 1995 vintage that I had in 2001.

2002 vintage - hazy bright and dark orange colour with a little white foam; very complex aroma of hay, rhubarb and grapefruit; medium-bodied, juicy and very acidic; somehow smooth; very long acidic aftertaste with more dust, vinegar and rhubarb - a great beer!

25 oz bottle, 2002 Vintage, via anders37, tasted side-by-side with a regular 3 F Oude Gueuze, Vintage 2004.  Absolutely perfect pour, slightly hazy gold under a nice fizzy foamy slightly off-white head that left some nice fine lacing.  The nose is just great as well, funky dry cellar mustiness with some granny smith apples, lemons, a little pixie stick dry sugariness and barnyard bretty funk.  Really no yogurty or cheesy funkiness that dominated the younger 2004 regular version.  Just a really mellow well aged gueuze that really hits the sweet spot of what I want.  The flavor is tart and a little acidic with a ton of dry cellar dust and must.  Lemon tartness and funky brett interplay perfectly.  A lingering oak and earthiness fades slowly on the finish.  Mouthfeel is completely attenuated leaving a crisp fairly light bodied feel with perfect lively spritzy carbonation.  This was truely great, and by far outshined the younger version in terms of drinkability.  Though the younger was beautiful in its own right.  I only wonder whether it was the lambics that went into the different bottles or simply the age of the bottles that made the huge difference.  I cant wait to see how the J&Js stand up to this.
Bottle Delirium Cafe (2003):  Pours a clear light copper color with a white head.  Aroma is hint of sweet malt and lots of tart fruit.  Flavor is a dry tart fruit with a long sour dry citrus finish.

UPDATED: DEC 15, 2008 April 12, 2002 Vintage. Poured from a 750ml Thanks to Jason. Aroma wicks forth with a flicking tongue of spring essence in a cherry orchard. Blossoms all around. Cottony wafts, sugars flaunt and a wheat essence plays with persimmon seeds and Passionfruit juice in a soft balance. Fleeting ginger. Pours that clear even gold, headed with mountains of residing billowy foam, lubricious in its delivery. Bubbly and alive. Flavor arrives in resplendent glory, with gentle tannins, refined sweetness and lots of elegant cotton. Pear juice and lemon oils. Tart, puckering and full of the necessary farm yard. This was tasted side by side with the standard Oude Geuze and this was hands down the winner. This maintains complex acidity and brightness, yet holds such refined softness and gentle, pleasing flavors. The young has cheese, wildness, wood and acid, this restrains those a little bit and yields soft spice, grassy fields and sunlight. Awesome stuff.

Rating #800. 2004 vintage. Murky orange pour heaped with lasting white froth. Fleshy, sherbety orange aroma with a hint of mouldy tangerine. Bitter orange and lemon fruitiness finishing with a dash of G+T dryness. Cleaner, spritzier and less complex than the younger versions Ive tried, with little dankness or wood. A delicious tingling beer dripping with tangy, citrussy fruit.

Dark orange. Fine white disappearing head. Classic Oude Geuze aroma with some sourness popping up and notes of lemon. In the mouth the sourness is medium lasting. Some woody flavors. A bit earthlike as well.

0.375 l bottle, vintage 2004. Copper to amber color with creamy head. Sour, earthy-leathery and parfumy aroma with notes of strawberry, pineapple and rose. Very sour, tart, woody and mouth drying flavor with pineapple and bitterness from the wild yeast. Very hard at first, but after a while palate got used to it.

37.5 cl bottle, bottled in 2003. Cloudy, light coppery, white frothy head. Fruity nose: orange peel, a hint of raspberries. Also brett, matchsticks, a bit herbal. Dry, sour taste with citrus, soft fruit, flowing into apricot cake into a rather sharp bitter aftertaste. Filling, almost chewable body, satisfying fizz.

Bottle, GBBF 07. Cloudy golden with a thin white head. Nose is lively, slightly vinous and sherberty. Some nice fruit. Mouth is sharp and slightly acetic, fruitiness grows sweeter. Finishes with a sour freshness. Really good.

Bottled: March 7th 02. Hazy golden orange color, big frothy head. Nicely balanced aroma of tart gueuze, but still quite soft, some cork however. Bit fruity, some horseblanket. Nice strong taste, quite tart, not too sweet, slight carbonating. Quite decent gueuze.

bottle, dated 7/3/03. thanks ygtbsm. pours a glowing orangish-copper with white head. nose is barnyard, tart, lemony and citrus. very nice. flavor is tart lemon, funky, hay, nicely rounded out acidity and sourness. very fruity gueze but the palate is a little flat and short. wonderful, but i preferred their regular oude geuze.

Bottle of 2002 and 2003 head to head, 2002 from antwerp, 2003 from ronnie. 2002 has a really fresh crisp sharp lambic funk, noteably sour. 2003 is similar but there are subtlties that differenciate the two. Taste 2002 again seems fresher increadibly carbonated, too much for me to be honest, cidery palete, sour funk, noteable belgiunness about it. 2003 had more body too it, not as complex, less carbonated and increadibly drinkable. If pushed id say the 2002 is a better beer, but both are complete masterpieces that i want alot more of.
Bottle. Vintage 2003. Golden colour with a white head. Aroma is sour, acid,apple. Flavour is sour, apple, yeast, acid. Very nice beer.

Sparkling gold, fluffy head - much more than Im used to in a lambic.  Nose is acid, light wheaty hay, maybe a hint of strawberry.  Flavor is a hit of lemon, lots of acidity, flowers, then strong sour undefined in the finish.  Leaves me wanting more.

UPDATED: JAN 24, 2010 750 ml bottle. Hazy golden body with a fine white head. Aroma is classic geuze, acidic, fruity, barnyard, horse blanket etc. Same goes for the flavors, refreshing sour, acidic, mould, cellar notes, tart, grapefruit and some bitterness in the finish. Its a classic geuze with a very fine and balanced  expression. Compared with a Cantillon a had earlier its a little bit more smooth in my opinion. Regarding what your personal preference will be for a geuze it could be either less or more advantage. I think its close to perfection for a geuze. (re-ratet)
Vintage 2002 from bottle. A very nice not to sour beer with soem sweetness in it. Very complex taste

Bottle @ Le Bier Circus. Vintage 2002. Huge fizzy white head that mostly diminished. Copper colour with a clear sparkling body. Dust, barnyard, ash, citrus, perfume, tobacco, wood, vanilla, unripe apple. Medium to full bodied with a soft carbonation and dry texture. Flavour was not as sour as expected. Still it was light to moderated acidic with some sweet notes left in the flavour. Excellent dry finish.

Sour, farmy, coppery aroma with flavors including tart grapefruit and, well, old socks. Just a drop of sweetness before the funky, beautifully complexity kicks in. Occupied a happy medium between mellow drinkability and harsh, acidic aridity. Awesome, but Ill keep some around a few more years and take another step toward the mellow end.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2010 Bottle sampled on 6/6/10: Pours with good lacing and a large frothy off-white head.  Has a good complex funky barnyard nose with light sweetness and lemon zest.  Body has good dry earthy tartness and some lightly sweet balance with oaky complexity before a puckering tartness.  A very enjoyable gueuze.



Bottle sampled on 2/13/07: Pours a hazy dark golden bronze with a frothy, well-lacing white head.  Dry, earthy, funky cheesy barnyard aroma has decent complexity.  Body starts fairly full and with an earthy pale maltiness, nicely-balanced with a good, drier cheesy complexity toward a slightly bready finish.  A nice gueuze.

Date de mise en bouteille 07/03/2003. Hazy orange-gold with a large white head. Aroma of yeast, sour apple and dewy spring cottage garden. The taste is grapefruit with dusty books and paper stored in old barns and attics. Sour, but if you persevere you pick out a distant honey sweetness. The result is fresh, clean, immensely drinkable: a wonderful example of the brewers craft. This is the reason I love beer.
Bottle.  Golden beer with a strongish head.  The aroma is quite sour with a sweet finish, the flavour is very sour with a vinegar and dry finish.  Overall an average beer.

Bottle. Careful when you open the bottle. The cork and metal really comes in handy here. Small and quickly disappearing white head. Hazy orange body. Complex fruity aroma and flavor of oranges and some kind spice I cannot really figure out. For a geuze this is relatively sweet still, though, with a pleasant sharp edge.

Huge pungent Gueze-y nose: funky, horse blanket mustiness, the whole thing. Dark murky gold color with a low head. Soft malt base with a hint of apples. Sour and puckering end. Smooth overall and amazingly well balanced. Sophisticated and unique. Nice!

Bottle dated 07/03/03. I honestly dont know what t o make of this beer. Ive had geuze before, but this was such an extreme example. The beer is a lovely honey colour in the glass with a big foam head. The strong aroma has bags of apples, sourness, musty animal smells and a hint of sweetness. Describing the flavour does it no justice at all - is at once foul and appealling. In one mouthfull it is a musty, sour, eye-wateringly sour with the smell of a restaurant kitchine floor - old cheese and rotten veg. Another taste is tart but refreshing, light bodied with a citrus tang, oakey dryness in the finish. Its either disgusting or the most complex brilliant beer youll drink and I honestly cannot decide which.

2003. Aroma of citrus, forests and yeast. Hazy, orange coloured with an initially huge, white head. Taste is moderate tart, woody, dusty, quite fruity (citric), somewhat sweet, some yeast. Balance is perfect. Very refreshing and dry. Excellent brew.
2002.  Hazy light orange with a small but steady white head. Aromas of lemon, grapefruit, hay, barnyard, leather, even a bit of mushroom. Tart, acid, slightly yeasty and musty flavour. Very dry.

UPDATED: MAY 1, 2007 Drunk at One Pint Pub, Helsinki during the Belgian beer week 2007. Vintage 2002. A bit damp aroma, fruity and dry. Nice hazy orange, quick head. Very dry, fuity and a but of a yeasty taste. Vintage 2003 got better grades.

UPDATED: SEP 2, 2007 Bottle from Uto. Golden yellow with foamy white head. As effervescent as champagne. Lemon lime nose with vinegar. Taste of tart lime - not far off from sour mix. Yeasty, but light. Hints of red berries. Dry, acidic finish. Perfectly balanced. Refreshing and crisp. Quality stuff. Afterthought: the barnyard character came to the surface after last pour, presumably from the sediment. A more careful pour should prevent this nastiness.
Vintage 2002: Sour yeasty mineral aromaa. Bittersweet yeasty taste with cirus, herbs, barn and horse. Bitter sour aftertaste.

Vintage 2002:  Poured a hazy dark yellow color with a large white head.  Semi-sweet aroma with a good amount of horsey, yeasty funk.  Some sweaty feet notes.  The flavor was very tart and mildly acidic.  Some sweetness in there.  Short dry finish but the tartness makes your mouth water.  Mild bitterness on the finish.  Yummy.

Pours a hazy orange color with a thin white head. Excellent aroma of hay, belgian funk and citrus, its also sour and lactic. Excellent flavor of hay, citrus, sourness,belgian faund and some sweetness, the sweetness is kind of surprising. The body is light to medium with a dusty mouthfeel and medium carbonation. Great stuff.

Bottled - 2002 Vintage.  A hazy orange coloured beer with no head.  The aroma is sour, funky and welcoming.  Barnyard and cheesy notes aplenty.  A really inviting smell just shouting "Drink me".  The taste is puckeringly sour and dry.  Tart and grapey.  Just a really lovely drink.

07/03/2002 bottle courtesy of Christian.
Audible effervescence from this murky mustard and apple juice body with a fizzy fluffy white head. The strange yet comforting aroma hit me and made my mouth start watering. I can already frrl it in my jaws and I have not even tasted it yet. Sweaty nose that in all other circumstances scares me makes me smile in this beer. Lemon sour with wood flavor and some orange puckering notes. So much acidity in such a small bottle. Sour leather finish. I dont know why it is that I can like what I would otherwise detest in any other type of beer. But a nice and funky geuze is is so damn good. And this is a nice and funky geuze. Lingering band aid flavor is a bit of a negative, but not overly so. A great beer, that I want more of. Thanks so much Christian, Im in your debt.
5 8 8 5 19

2002 Vintage, bottle at Ealing Beer Festival, April 2006. Hazy orange colour. Good strong horse blanket funky aroma. Excellent sharp, citric flavour with musty, woody undertones. Quite clean mouthfeel and finish. Classic geuze.

UPDATED: FEB 6, 2009 2002 vintage sampled at the RB gathering at capt lawrence.  Funkier aroma than a 99, and a bit less sour/tart- more earthy and spicy with a nice sourness though.  Nice more4 tart flavor, with some lemony sitrus tart-like quality and a battery acid finish and funkiness all the way through.  Nice spritzy yet smooth carbonation and a nice lingering finish.  Great Gueze.  Vintage 2002 4.1,  vintage 2005 4.3.

Bottle. Amber beer with no head. Tart, oaky aroma. Tart flavor with apples, earthiness, and yeast. Low carbonation. Lingering tartness.

25/10 first ratebeer entry: Vintage 03. Hazy with white head. Sour aroma with citrus and lots of cellar...Sour in flavour with berries and quite fresh. 8-3-7-3-14

Vintage 2003.  Cloudy golden copper body with a large white head.  Some barnyard in the aroma with green apples and hay.  Green apples is the main taste and it comes with its usual sourness and acidic finish.  Acidity level is average for the style.  Side by side with a Girardin Black Label (the reference?) this one was almost as good, a bit more fruity and lacking the brettyness of the BL it was nonetheless sharper and more aggressive. Excellent.  BEWARE: I also brought back a bottle home that proved to be disappointing (mellow, too fruity, lacking punch).  Being a positive person Im only rating on the good one.  I wish women would do the same with my performances.

Hazy orange, low head.
Iron Notes, leather, horseblanket.
Spongy retronasal. Quite subdued really. Dry finish. Sparkly mouthfeel -slightly overcarbonated.

UPDATED: SEP 20, 2006 Bottled 4/13/02... This beer rocks!... Murky golden ale with a huge, wispy, white head. Great retention. The nose is acidic with a lot of funkiness; sharp cheese, lemon, wet leather and barnyard. Well-balanced for a gueuze. Just enough sweetness to hold the acidity down... unusual for a gueuze.  Medium-bodied and a bit creamy with fizzy carbonation. Different world class! Thanks to marsiblursi for providing the bottle!

750mL, bottled 04.13.02; many thanks to hopscotch for bringing this along.  Pours a large, off-white head, good retention and lacing; cloudy yellowish-brown appearance.  Enticing, citrus and barnyard funk in the aroma.  Nice, chewy tartness up front; medium-to-low acidity, fruity, citrusy core; something of a belgian ale profile buried underneath.  Medium, tart finish.  A fantastic, drinkable gueze rendition.

(750ml bottle, bottled 4/13/02, thanks hopscotch) Cloudy apple juice body topped by a big white head that mostly dissipates.  Aroma is mildly sweet, barnyard, some vinegar, funk.  Taste is minimally sweet, horseblanket, lemon, funk, vinegar, light lime.  Solid sourness, but not overwhelming.  Somewhat dry finish.  Light body, light acidity.

375ml bottle, 07/03/2002 (march?), thanks to Madsberg as a bonus in trade!  deep dark golden, mostly clear body with a good amount of fizz moving up the middle.  big off-white fluffy and foamy head.  aroma is tart apple, apple cider vinegar, and a little dusty leather.  flavor is dry and tart, a little like dandelion greens, unripe sour cherries, and a little acidity.  carbonation is very tingly, makes the mouthfeel fizzy/foamy.  finish starts dry, goes tart, then clean, then fizzy again.  aftertaste is a faded dryness.  big thanks, Madsberg!!
Defenitely even better than the other. It was sour and sweet at the same time, just impossible not to like. NIce colour and foam. Everything on it was great. The aftertaste is good.

Any first impressions?
-A ring of foam surrounds the veiled orange murk.
-Flowery orange juice is prominent, undermined by funky hay.
-The citrusy fruitiness and lemon and orange pulp prevails over the crispy wheat; this still remains sweeter than the usual 3 Fonteinen Oude Gueuze.
-The prickly carbonation cannot hide the fuller mouthfeel than usual.

What if you dig deeper?
-Peppery funk tickles the back of the tongue.
-I dont feel this is as clean and cohesive as the usual Oude Gueuze.
-Sourness is pleasantly puckering, yet does not overdo it.

Bottle; 16/04/2002.

Hazy golden gueuze with a thin white head. Wonderful aroma of sweet ground cherries, leather, dust, and basement. In mouth, a restrained gueuze ewith light cherries, tart, gypsum and lactic acid. A smooth gueuze, a bit lighter than expected but very good. Enjoyed with the Mtl Crew Sept. 9, 2006.

vintage 2002. Medium orange color, cloudy, white head. Incredibly sharp, pungent beer. Light bitterness, very sour, long biting aftertaste. High acid level, funky as hell. Delicious stuff. Thanks again Jeff

(Vintage 2002). Orange colored, vanishing white head. Ok, what can there be else than strong dryness, sourness and some fruits, good and rich aroma indeed. Medium bodied. Extremely sour and dry flavored lambic with fruity tones also. Aftertaste lasts long!

UPDATED: NOV 28, 2006 Aroma: very sourish, musty, flowery, vaguely soap-like, dandelion, lovely malt, leather, grass, apple peel, smoky, slightly burnt, cheeselike.  Appearance: turbid fruity orange yellow with yellowtinted, white head - which looks very healthsome.  Flavor: sour, not that strong, soft, vinous, some bitterness, full-bodied aftertaste, tannic acid?, acrid somehow, very dry. - weak, watery   Palate: pretty much co2 but w/ a fanstastic body, fat, meaty, sparkling noble.  Very special, dry and noble.
Smoky, sour and fruity aroma. In the taste you find acidity, smoke, some fruit and alot of oak (?) wood barrel.

First of all, massive, MASSIVE thanks to diabel for sending me this. I owe you big-time!Clear amber with an anemic head which does its best to hang on to the bottom of the glass. Loads of stuff going on in the aroma in a very refined kinda way - classic 3F really. There are those Vervifontaine-style wildflowers, violets and fresh-cut grass with something thats reminiscent of the Pajottenland countryside itself - cowdung? Balsa wood, sawdust, cherries, pepper, lemon rind, sherbet, musty cobwebs and moisturiser all get a bit of a run too, with some prickly volatile acids getting into the nasal cavity. Very dry and quite light-bodied with no real initial sweetness at all, before an assertive but certainly not aggressive orange juice tartness which persists for quite some time. What certainly is aggressive is a rough, astringent, woody, stale hop bitterness which is alright and quite interesting but does get a bit much in parts, giving a finish like super-strength tonic water. Mouthfeel is quite round, with only moderate carbonation, but the considerable tannic presence makes it quite interesting. The bitterness is a bit awkward but this is still delightful stuff. Really bright flavours, vibrant and fresh. Its quite amazing to think its already four years in the bottle. Top stuff.

Thank you so much Anthony for bringing this treasure along to our little mini gathering in Hamburg. Murky orange color with a big fluffy head on top. Fizzy carbonation. Bubble gum orange nose. Pungeant - orange taste - balanced - very nice.
[750ml bottle] Orange colour with a slight haze. Rich head. Earthy, acidic barnyard aroma. Very smooth and balanced with taste of rhubarb and iron.

Bottled. Hazy orange in colour. Rich bubbly white head. Minor lacings. It has a earthy and barnyardish aroma. The flavour is fresh and earthly. Sour with fruits and some citric scents. There is a sweet and sour aftertaste.

Bottled (thanks omhper). Firstly, the cork flew in the wooden roof, and almost broke it, so beware of high pressure. A bit hazy golden colour, mediumsized head. Aroma is sourness and fruits. Flavour is dry and sour oak. Extremely smooth to drink. Long sour fruitish aftertaste. Just superb!
[bottle from GBBF 06] Musky barnyard aromas over acidic citrus fruits, soft and complex. Full bodied, dry, tart refreshing.

UPDATED: MAY 21, 2009 Bottle. Very sour, slightly earthy aroma. Cloudy dark orange colour. Stable white head. Nice and soft flavour, but still nicely sour. The flavour is also earthy. I do not get any funky, unsettling flavours. Nice, sourish bitterness. 8 3 8 4 18

Bottle, 6% at KØ09. Beautiful mild and citric aroma, nicely earthy. Very nice citric flavour. Dry and earthy and very good. 8 3 8 3 18

Brown-orange, cloudy with firm white head.
Acidic aroma with notes of wheat, roasted malts, citrus, fruit, rock and mushrooms.
Acidic flavor with notes of citrus, malt and popcorn. Dry.

Bottled.
Hazy orange color, decent white head. Sour, barnyardish aroma. Very carbonated mouthfeel. Fruity, sour, but not so sour like eg. typical Cantillon. Grapefruit and earthy notes dominate. Refreshing summer drink.

UPDATED: NOV 10, 2006 Vintage 2002. 375ml bottle at the <a
href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Place/sweden/s target=blank>Akkurat in Stockholm, Sweden.  Golden-orange in colour.  Long lasting off-white head, great lacing.  The aroma is tart, acidic upfront, sour apples, lemons, pears, light honey.  The flavour was quite tart and acidic but beautifully balanced with lemon citrus, grapes and green apple skins, some funky cheese.  Sour mouthfeel, medium body, high carbonation.  Finishes long and tart, long apple sweeteness then very dry.  Fantastic stuff, another gem from this brewery.

Pale amber (almost dark gold) in colour with mild sparkling wine-like carbonation. Aromas of lemon, wet hay, barnkyard, paint, black pepper, and mild cherry. All sorts of crazy flavors with this one: lactic acid, horse blanket, wet cedar wood, earth, and mozarella cheese at the end. The palate is quite interesting, as it starts out with medium fullness, but dries VERY quickly. Great sourness and complexity... somewhat Cantillon-like, but a bit more woody. Wow!

Pours yellow with a thin white head.  Smells grassy with hay, lots of wildflowers, sugar, gasoline, mellow subdued fruit.  Tastes dry with a the initial sourness giving way to nice fruity undertones.  Finishes woody with some brett character.

Aroma:  pineapple, honey, peaches, cream, flowers, sourness, and mint

Appaerance:  murky golden orange, small white head

Flavor:  sour, mint, gum, grassiness, and honey

Palate:  smooth with light sourness--not very aggressive--light mint aftertaste

This beer has a hazy orange colour with a small firm white head. The nose is acidic and complex. The flavour is acidic and very refreshing. When your pour the sediment in your beer it tastes even better. (Corked bottle 75cl)

UPDATED: AUG 26, 2010 Bottled, 375 ml, 07.03.2002. Oak, honey, lemon and a hint of pepper in the perfect aroma. Sour flavor, but an eased down sourness, not too harsh. Oak, lemon, grapefruit, raspberry. Still some sharp edges, that need to be eased down by further cellaring. Great balance, great potential. Very long oaky and citric aftertaste. Close to perfection, I wish Id bought more bottles. 

Bottle 375 ml, vintage 2-2005. Special label. Honey, lemon and sewer in the aroma. Sour flavor with sewer, lemon, grapefruit, oak, honey and rubber. Very complex and especially aromatic, but the aftertaste is too rubbery. (8 4 8 3 16 = 3.9)

Bitten gav en omgang og vi andre nød det. (hov! jeg må vist hellere tale for mig selv)

Lys orange farve med et hvidt skum.
Det sprudler af syre i smagen og duften, masser af brus.
Smager hengemt og lidt af jord og træagtig.
Det er ment på den gode måde.......
Uuuuhmmmmm....dette kan jeg lide rigtig godt.

Bottle, 750 ml. Hazy orange colour, fast receding fizzy white head. Wonderful grapefruit aroma with woody and metallic elements. Acidic citric flavour with a soft finish. A great beer, Ill buy another bottle. Open carefully, I sent the cork into orbit...

Bottle (375 ml)  Orange, hazy body.  Off-white frothy head, which disappears instantly.  Dusty aroma with hints of wood, lemon.  There are better smelling gueuzes.  Moderately bitter, lightly sour initial flavour.  Heavily sour, lightly bitter finish.  Totally different than the other Drie Fonteinen beers: somewhat more tart, somewhat familiar of the one of champagne.  But still very nice balance and mouthfeel.  Very fizzy carbonation.  It resembles champagne very much due to its tartness and carbonation.

Bottle. Very hazy with an pale orange colour, topped with a dense vreamy white head. Fresh grapefruity and lemony anroma with notes of wood, stable, rubharb, with very light and fresh sweetness of pears. Dry woody flavour with strong notes of red grapefruit and old cheese. Smooth mouthfeel.. Tart grapefruity finish with light bitter woody aftertaste. Beautiful stuff.

(bottle) It pours amber to orange with a big fairly fast decreasing head. Unclear.
Sharp, fresh smell. Seawater. Gooseberry. Wooden-sprots. Sawdust.
The taste is an attac of sourness that puts chills all over your body. Continues with lemon-acid. Cranberryjuice. Tart taste. Un-ripe gooseberry. Fizzy with sharp carbination. Green banana-skids. Wooden-sprouts. A great handcraft!

UPDATED: JUN 11, 2013 375ml bottle, vintage 2002
Consumed at Oud Arsenal, Antwerp, May 2006 (4 years cellared)

Fruity, frothy crackers and dry pears and resiny sap.  Exceptional soothing aftertaste.  I found myself noting that this was similar to a few Cantillon gueuze and lambik bottles.  Everything about this beer is astounding.

UPDATED: OCT 28, 2012 2012-10-28, corked half bottle, 9-5-8-3-17=42bottled 10/02/2005, bb 02/2015, 7+ years oldLabel "De Nachtlichten" by Schilderij Felix De BoeckHazy amber color with frothy generous head. The aroma is sour, with cellar smells, a bit citrusy, wood (chestnut honey like) and lightly corky too. The mouthfeel is smooth, well carbonated; tart and a bit astringent; plenty of citrus peel, oranges and grapefruits; dry; fat final, woody.This is an imposing Gueuze, big more than elegant.2006-06-05, corked half bottle, 9-5-8-5-17=44Hazy blond color; giant head; intense and fine perlage. Over a soft malt there is an extreme astringency; the sourness is ordinary for this kind of beer; at the end the astringency dominates again, with grapefruit sourness and fruitness, and bitter orange peels. UPDATED: OCT 11, 2006 2002 - Unclear golden body with a huge white head; Big very nice nose, but not the usual one: wood, cedar, pine, resin, ripe grapefruit; Very well balanced body, soft, with big a little sharp carbonation; Into long very balanced sour acidy finish with some harsh grapefruit peel, some oak it is very complex and quite hard to take apart. I find the harshness of the finish to aparent.

Bottle (375ml): Big stinky cheese aroma, and that wasnt just the cheese nearby! Old grapes, rotting fruit and socks are all there. Very fresh fruity flavour, quite soft and pleasant. Tart but balanced, with nice grape + apple juicy notes. Really tasty. Cheers to duff for picking up and passing on!

Bottled. Aroma of barnyard, oak and sour apples. Hazy, yellow color, off-white head, few lace. Light sweet, malts, oak, tart, sparkling and woody dry. Really beautiful, very lively, all the flavors are there and in between the roughness of a younger geuze and the softness of an older geuze.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2014 2002 vintage (2006 release) 375mL bottle from Engelsmann, shared with SuIIy on 5/20/06.Magnificent pour, though that hardly needs saying, as the intrigue lies not in the appearance of these wonderful beers.  "We" all know that the appearance is perfect.  Enough said.The nose plays a familar tune as lively brett, deepened by a growing lactobacillus influence dries things heavily.  Musty, old yeasts, near the plasticy/rubber, but without all the brashness and exuberance of that one.  But for sure, this is anything but dull.  I think this grows cheesy, as SuIIy points out quickly.  It better get funky, and it certainly does.  Though without the oily pediococcus and clear oak streaks.  I apologize for comparing it, so blatantly to Cantillon, but its only meant to be flattering.The palate is, surprisingly tame and rather loose for a gueuze.  Though never watery, with a full (as full as fully attenuated can get) and quenching body.  Well, getting back to the flavor, first sip again shows tons of Orval-esque brett before you get blown out of the water by hard lactic acid.  Certainly much more serious than any previous Oude Gueuze done here, and very promising.Joris enters it as a new beer, and I had no idea why, but after tasting it, its just so clear.  The aroma and first couple of notes dont remind me, but the middle and finish remind me strongly of de Cam 2001 oude gueuze.

750ml bottle gratiously shared by ClarkVV on 5/20/06. Pours a dark golden color with a small white head. Loads of tiny bubbles stream throughout the glass racing towards the top. Nose is some sour lemons with a touch of cheesiness and some light musty funk notes. A very fresh scent to it. Palate is quite fizzy and much sourness on the tongue. Leaves a great film on the palate and a big sour bitterness in the finish. Flavorful notes of  Lemony citrus sourness, some more great cheese notes, leaves an everlasting sour note on your lips. My palate is torn between sour lemon and very strong cheese notes that leave a bit of dryness in the mouth. Some more dry fruits mingle into the scene trying to avoid the sourness and make themselves noted, light apricot and tangerine the main battlers. That cheese essence is so strong and forceful, it leaves a nice thick taste in the back of your throat. To conclude, Id like to thank ClarkVV for the chance to try this even though he opened it on accident and finish by saying this is amazing, complex and delightful.

Bottle. Pours a foggy orange body with a medium-sized frothy head. Beautiful woody pine aroma , oranges, and cheese. Very sharp right up front - mainly citrus (grapefruit) twang and effervescent carbonation. Tart apples and cheesiness reappear. Excellent gueuze.

Sampled at Oud Arsenaal in Antwerp on May 10, 2006.
Hazy orange colour with a white head. Tart fruity aroma with notes of earth and wood. Wellbalanced sweet / sour flavor with some fruityness. Dry yeasty finish.
Bottle. Deep orange golden with a fine white geuze head. Complex aroma of wood and citrus. Sharply acidic, citrus, with dry wood (oak) taking over towards the finish. Fizzy. A great beer it is.
300th Belgian Beer Rating. Bottle at Ealing Beer on Broadway Festival, 2006. Cloudy orange. Lovely lemony/citrus aroma. Sharp citrus, fruit, lip smackering. Very dry, woody and tart. Very nice.

UPDATED: JUL 13, 2013 Hazy golden colour with a small white head. Light acid, sour, fruity(lemon), barnyard, horseblanket aroma and taste, dry. Medium body with a dry finish.Ja dat is het. #400 I need to cellar this before rerating it, still a bit to sharp.
Edit: 13-7-2013, same vintage, only after cellaring it for 11y, horseblanket is much less pronounced, its less sharp, more fruity, like banana and still lots of lemon, I get the idea that its highened in abv. Awesome beer to lay for a decade.
Bottle thanx to Jeppe. Hazy golden colour with a small white head. Light acid, sour, fruity, barnyard aroma and taste, dry. Medium body with a dry finish.

Bottled.  Hazy golden, firm fluffy head. Distinct citric nose where barnyard is very evident. Soft, lively and juicy with concentrated flavours. Acidic and ultra-complex, yet frefreshingly drinkable. A super premium gueuze.

Bottle - corked and caged. Bubbly gold body with an effervescent white head. Nose is horseblanket, barnyard notes, light cat urine, tart fruits, and sweaty socks. Taste is delicious! Lots of tart fruits, barnyardy notes, light wood, earthy flavors, light sweat, damp basement, etc. Typical Drie Fonteinen and typical Drie Fonteinen quality! Body is tart and acidic but light and bubbly, as the style seems to dictate. Finishes with more sour fruits, damp earthiness, light wood, and barnyard notes. Great stuff!

Bottle @ Kulminator.  2002 Vintage.  Pretty happy to get my hands on this one.  Green label, green glass, golden pour, huge head.  Massively bubbly, slightly cloudy, fantastic stuff.  Sour and complex.  Champagney with an off-note somewhere between light cheese and fresh tire (Ill go with astringency).  Musty and challenging.  Very funky, probably needs time to grow on me.  Strange and beautiful.

Bottle. Light golden coloured with a consistant small white head. Slightly moldy but in a fresh way. Tastes a bit "dusty". High carbonation. Very fruity and flavour of grapefruit. A nice dryness in the aftertaste. Very good.

An unclear orange beer with a thin white head. The aroma is super acidic with notes of grapefruit and wood, and the flavor is also lovely acidic with lots of grapefruit notes, and with a dry metallic end.

(Bottle 37,5 cl) Pours a hazy honey golden with a creamy, off-white head. Distinct acidity in the nose, but also fruit, barnyard, manure and horse sweat - all the usual Brett characteristics. Light body with lots of fruitiness, citrus - grapefruit in particular - and acidity. But actually surprisingly smooth and mellow. This is not the kinda gueuze that makes your tongue crumble. UPDATED: MAR 11, 2006 Pours beautiful hazy orange golden with a rocky white head that lasts forever. Nice and extremely well balanced sour aroma with grapefruit, lemon, bready and vague woody notes - nice!! Flavor is just as balanced and extremely smooth in the mouth. Has a very nice sour grapefruit note that isnt tart at all, but velvety on the tongue. Very cleansing almost lemonady, I could drink this forever. One of the best and most balanced gueuzes I have had! Thank you Armand for brewing this beauty!

Hazy, grainy-coloured beer; fast receding whitish head. Very nice lemony-citrussy nose over horseblanket and distinctly wheat. Very mild,  malse  gueuze. Smoked, grainy, near sweet-malty notes, sweet muscat grapes. Better filled than most gueuzes, slick (restsweetness? couldnt be with Brett). Another superb try by Armand. Definitely within the 3 Fonteinen frame - they all resemble each other a bit, but are all just great.
